headline: It’s Infrastructure Week!
abstract: Mr. Trump, here’s a fight worth having.

headline: Would You Let the Police Search Your Phone?
abstract: We are much more likely to give consent than we think.
lead_paragraph: Law enforcement officers on the doorstep threatening to “come back with a warrant” is a cliché of police procedural dramas. Things are much less dramatic in real life: The officers ask if they can take a look around, and the civilians say yes without putting up a fight.

headline: Alabama Is More Pro-Immigrant Than You Think
abstract: White evangelicals are tired of letting their fear of outsiders outweigh their duties as Christians.
lead_paragraph: MONTGOMERY, Ala. — When we think about where immigrants head once they arrive in the United States, we usually imagine them piling into border states like Texas and urban areas along the coast. And many do.

headline: Trump, Seeking to Put Pressure on Maduro, Threatens a Full Embargo on Cuba
abstract: Mike Pompeo, the secretary of state, said in an interview with CNN that Mr. Maduro had planned to flee to Cuba on Tuesday, but was urged by the Russian government to stay.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Tuesday accused Cuba of aiding the government of President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela, who the administration evidently hoped would be ousted by day’s end, warning that the United States would impose an embargo and additional sanctions on the country if Cuba did not end its support.

headline: Judge Overturns Conviction of Ex-Penn State President in Sandusky Case
abstract: The president, Graham Spanier, had been convicted on a misdemeanor charge related to failing to report the abuse of a boy by Jerry Sandusky.

headline: Peacocks, but Not Peahens
abstract: Joel Fagliano springs a pop quiz on us.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — To some solvers, crossword puzzles can feel like a test of what they know and what they don’t know. There is some truth to that, but I like to look at it another way: My brain, like Joel Fagliano’s, loves to collect facts and store them away greedily until I can find some unsuspecting person to spring them on.

headline: Mets Blow Lead in Ninth but Pete Alonso Wins Game in Tenth
abstract: The rookie first baseman hit a sacrifice fly that was the difference in a win over Cincinnati in which Jeurys Familia failed to secure a six-out save.
lead_paragraph: Continuing his strong rookie season, Pete Alonso hit a game-winning sacrifice fly off Raisel Iglesias in the 10th inning, and the Mets rebounded from a blown ninth-inning lead to beat the Cincinnati Reds, 4-3, on Tuesday night. In doing so, the Mets avoided dropping below .500 for the first time this year.

keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)', 'Constitutions', 'Royal Families', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: Japan’s emperor bypassed the government by asking the people to endorse his departure.

His decision is widely being described as a break from a 200-year tradition. In fact, it is a return to an older, even longer-standing tradition, with a modern twist.

headline: Examining Identity, Race and Responsibility Among White South Africans
abstract: Sydelle Willow Smith’s photos tease out the complexities of her white South African compatriots, who grapple with the question of national origin.
lead_paragraph: As a white South African, Sydelle Willow Smith grew up keenly aware of her country’s tangled history of colonialism, race and privilege. Though she was raised in a liberal Jewish family active in the movement against apartheid, Ms. Smith still felt uneasy when she went to take photographs in townships. It was as if the country’s colonial era’s exploitation of natural resources, which shaped the continent itself, was mirrored in the very act of making a photograph.

headline: How Exercise Affects Our Memory
abstract: Even a single workout may make our brain’s memory centers, like our muscles, more fit.
lead_paragraph: A single, moderate workout may immediately change how our brains function and how well we recognize common names and similar information, according to a promising new study of exercise, memory and aging. The study adds to growing evidence that exercise can have rapid effects on brain function and also that these effects could accumulate and lead to long-term improvements in how our brains operate and we remember.

headline: Deconstructing Australia’s Most Instagrammed Dessert
abstract: An at-home version of Sydney’s prized strawberry, watermelon and rose cake.
lead_paragraph: As a tourist, I am predictable: I am sugar-driven. Guava Danish and hot churros in Mexico City. Shaved ice and slippery mochi in Tokyo. The first time I went to Sydney, I rode a bus to Bondi Beach with a bag of Australian supermarket sweets on my lap. I toured the botanical gardens and walked around the Sydney Opera House, and then I planned the afternoon around a trip to Black Star Pastry in Newtown, so I could eat a slice of Christopher Thé’s famous strawberry-and-watermelon cake.

As a longtime employment lawyer, she had negotiated settlements for companies dealing with harassment claims. Now, as the country’s sex discrimination commissioner, she knew chief executives who were emphatic about gender equity, in pay and promotion.

headline: ‘King James Goes Down!’: How the Internet Turned on LeBron
abstract: There’s a distinct glee people find in watching a hero brought low.
lead_paragraph: On the internet, mockery often follows adoration. For a while, we take pride in the leaders we’ve chosen, forgiving their frailties, basking in their accomplishments, taking their victories as evidence of our own wisdom in exalting them. But do we really want our heroes to believe they’re better than us? Resentment builds quietly. When a hero’s weaknesses start to show, we circle like hyenas, smirking and sneering: He was always a bit arrogant, and she was so overpaid, and did you see his bald spot?

headline: When Dawoud Bey Met David Hammons
abstract: In the ’80s, a portrait photographer coming into his own captured an enigmatic artist creating his own legend. Rarely exhibited, the images are here, and at Frieze New York.
lead_paragraph: In 1981, the artist David Hammons and the photographer Dawoud Bey found themselves at Richard Serra’s T.W.U., a hulking Corten steel monolith installed just the year before in a pregentrified and sparsely populated TriBeCa. No one really knows the details of what happened next, or if there were even details to know aside from what Mr. Bey’s images show: Mr. Hammons, wearing Pumas and a dashiki, standing near the interior of the sculpture, its walls graffitied and pasted over with fliers, urinating on it.

headline: ‘UglyDolls’ Review: Stay Ugly, Friends

Milder in design than old-school troll dolls, these figures have a message: Idiosyncrasies of appearance and personality are not “ugly,” but rather emblems of awesome individuality. The relentless positivity of this fable is put across with such bounce-house energy that children in the audience may be bludgeoned into submission instantly. (It made this adult’s teeth hurt.)

headline: What to Cook in a Changing Climate

This fact can leave a home cook paralyzed at the stove or in the marketplace, choosing between the lamb and the tofu, the heritage carrots and the farm-raised fish. What to buy, if you want to help reduce your carbon footprint, the carbon footprint of our nation, our world? What to cook?

headline: What Do Europeans Really Want?
abstract: This month’s E.U. elections aren’t a fight between nationalists and progressives. They are total chaos.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — In less than a month, Europeans will cast their ballots to elect the next European Parliament. If you read the Continent’s major newspapers and listen to political leaders, you will come to believe that the European electorate is radically polarized and voters are prepared to make a fateful choice. The elections this month, we often hear, will become a kind of referendum. The far right expects it to be a referendum on migration (or more accurately, on Brussels’s failure to deal with it), while progressive pro-Europeans foresee it as a referendum on the very survival of the European Union. Far-right strategists hope that the election will resemble Donald Trump’s 2016 victory, while pro-European progressives expect the elections to resemble the second round of the presidential vote in France in 2017, when Emmanuel Macron defeated Marine Le Pen. Both sides, we are told, agree on one thing: We face a tribal war between populist-nationalists and committed Europeanists.

But there are alternative displays opening across the city this week, with modestly priced works by established and emerging artists. (These fairs are easier on the pocket and a little less overwhelming for casual browsers, too.) Here is a guide to some of them.

They were all trans women, and the line, Carmen Liu Lingerie, was full of pieces designed with them in mind.

headline: Was My Study Abroad Experience ‘Authentic’ Enough?
abstract: Making the jump from tourist to transient local is tough in the space of a few months. But is that even the point?
lead_paragraph: On any given morning, I’m on my bike: zipping around tight corners and down cobblestone alleyways, dodging tourists while simultaneously trying to not fall into canals on my way to school in Amsterdam’s city center. Like any good Amsterdammer, I’m a pro at swerving and dodging, racing a tram and cursing out the pedicabs that take up the entire bike lane. I like to think that I fit into the cityscape — that at a glance, I could pass for a local, instead of a student studying abroad. I can ride with no hands, after all.

headline: A Violent Splash of Magma That May Have Made the Moon
abstract: The object thought to have formed our lunar companion may have smashed into a baby Earth still covered in a fiery ocean.
lead_paragraph: The moon is far more than a largely dead orb. Our planet’s pale satellite is the creator of tides, the catcher of meteors and the only other world in the starry ocean where humanity has set foot. But scientists are still not entirely clear how it was made. Solving this mystery would not only reveal the moon’s origins, it would also help explain our own planet’s evolution.

headline: Vampire Weekend Wraps Breakdowns in Musical Smiles on ‘Father of the Bride’
abstract: The band’s fourth album is filled with perky tempos and sunny choruses, but its 18 songs grapple with personal breakups and global meltdowns.
lead_paragraph: Vampire Weekend has never made a peppier, happier-sounding album than “Father of the Bride.” It’s full of light-fingered guitars, perky tempos, winsome vocals and sunny, major-key choruses laced with poppy la-las and ooh-oohs. But that sound is definitely not to be trusted. For one thing, those upbeat choruses are carrying thoughts like, “How long till we sink to the bottom of the sea?” and “This life and all its suffering/Oh Christ, am I good for nothing?”

headline: The Uber I.P.O. Is a Moral Stain on Silicon Valley
keywords: ['Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles']
abstract: Ride-sharing was a good idea ruined by a deeply misguided start-up culture.
lead_paragraph: In 2010, I received an email from an ecstatic employee at a start-up called UberCab. “What our tiny company is doing for San Francisco right now is huge,” he told me. The employee’s joy was contagious. Back then, as a naïve, baby tech pundit, I was prone to spinning out elaborate visions of tech-abetted progress, and the more I learned about UberCab’s bold idea, the more deeply I swooned.

headline: #MeToo Is All Too Real. But to Better Understand It, Turn to Fiction.

Always the same nouns, she complains to us (scar, bruise, blood), always the same verbs (choke, starve, scream). The dull, depressing sameness of these stories. Their horrifying number.

headline: The Designer Reimagining Traditional West African Fabrics for a New Generation
abstract: From his studio in Lagos, Nigeria, Kenneth Ize works with local artisans to create innovative clothes from vibrant handcrafted textiles.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month in Lagos, Nigeria, the models Naomi Campbell and Alton Mason — she, an industry icon; he, one of the most in-demand faces in fashion now — walked the runway together at Arise Fashion Week, an annual showcase of ready-to-wear from across Africa. Striding hand in hand, they wore coordinating suits, finely striped and rendered in vivid colors (hibiscus pink, acid yellow), created by the Nigerian designer Kenneth Ize, whose work with hand-woven Yoruba aso oke fabrics, patterned textiles traditionally reserved for special occasions, has won him fans including Beyoncé, Donald Glover and Campbell. Ize, 29, founded his namesake label just three years ago, but his mission is already clear: “We’re reviving, reinterpreting and giving new context to artisan techniques that have given meaning to West African identity,” he says.

According to the Manhattan dermatologist Dr. Rachel Nazarian, there is an uptick in patients requesting brighter, clearer skin during this time of the year. For many, it’s a seasonal remedy for the dull dryness — or the “gray skin” effect, as her patients call it — that sets in during the winter, when humidity drops.

headline: Islamic State: Landless but Still Dangerous

Osama bin Laden had used the same props, as had Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, the first leader of the Islamic State, or ISIS.

headline: The Broadway Musical Has a Man Problem
abstract: From “Kiss Me, Kate” to “Tootsie,” shows old and new are working to reflect today’s gender politics. Women fare better, but what about the mediocre men?

headline: Saving the Teeth of Patients With Special Needs

abstract: A new dental center is built to welcome patients with special needs and those in wheelchairs, who often run into obstacles elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: Cheryl Closs, a mother of four from West Islip, N.Y., wanted to save her daughter Bella’s two front teeth. They were badly decayed, and one dentist wanted to just pull them out. But Ms. Closs was having none of it.

headline: Revealing the Terror of Sleep Paralysis
abstract: To help people understand a condition that frightened her at night, Ranita Roy used photography to visualize her experiences.
lead_paragraph: One rainy night in 2015, Ranita Roy was startled awake by the feeling that an intruder was in her bedroom. She tried yelling, but discovered she could not move a single muscle.

headline: In Sudan, a Dictator Fell, but Protesters Are Still Fighting
abstract: Even after forcing out President Omar al-Bashir, who ruled Sudan for 30 years, thousands of pro-democracy protesters are still out on the streets. Why? Because the country’s military generals have taken power into their hands.
lead_paragraph: Even after forcing out President Omar al-Bashir, who ruled Sudan for 30 years, thousands of pro-democracy protesters are still out on the streets. Why? Because the country’s military generals have taken power into their hands.

headline: Running in Bolivia
abstract: At just shy of 4,000 meters, my wheezing lungs and leaden legs remind me that I’m in foreign territory in every sense.
lead_paragraph: The teenager running alongside me, Luz, doesn’t say much. She is focused, her head dead straight, her stride landing rhythmically on the tarmac highway. Luz belongs to La Paz’s El Condor running club, which escapes the congestion of the city every Saturday for a training run up on the Bolivian high plateau, the altiplano. A small band of them have gathered for a recreational 10-mile run and kindly allowed me to join in.

headline: In Sudan, a Dictator Fell, but Protesters Are Still Fighting
abstract: Even after forcing out president Omar al-Bashir, who ruled Sudan for 30 years, thousands of pro-democracy protesters are still out on the streets. Why? Because the country’s military generals have taken power into their hands.
lead_paragraph: In April, widespread protests in Sudan led to the ouster of its longtime dictator, Omar al-Bashir. In May, Sudanese prosecutors charged him in connection with the killing of protesters.

headline: Review: ‘Tuca & Bertie’ Is an Eggsellent Adventure
abstract: A producer of “BoJack Horseman” creates a feminist friendship comedy that’s funny, haunting and visually surreal.
lead_paragraph: You may get the feeling, watching Netflix’s “Tuca & Bertie,” that you’ve seen these two birds somewhere before. How could you not? The series, which arrives Friday, is created by the “BoJack Horseman” producer and artist Lisa Hanawalt. It shares with “BoJack” a similar look and a roster of talking, paycheck-earning, occasionally depression-spiraling anthropomorphic animals.

headline: Anti-Infective Drugs Tied to Eating Disorders
abstract: The more infections or hospitalizations a girl had, the more likely she was to develop anorexia, bulimia or another eating disorder.
lead_paragraph: Girls who have serious or repeated infections in childhood are at higher risk for developing eating disorders in adolescence, a new study has found.

keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Urban Areas', 'United States Economy', 'Education', 'Nursing and Nurses', 'Vocational Training', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: For people without a college degree, finding work that offers decent pay can be a challenge. The solution may require a change in scenery.
lead_paragraph: You dropped out of college, or decided straight out of high school that college was not your thing. Here’s some advice if you are looking for a job: Stay out of Washington. Don’t go to New York. Forget about San Francisco. If you want to make anything near a decent wage, head for Toledo, Des Moines or Birmingham.

lead_paragraph: When the budget airline Wow Air abruptly ceased operations earlier this year, thousands of travelers were left stranded and scrambling, on both sides of the Atlantic, to make alternate travel plans.

keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Food Insecurity', 'Financial Aid (Education)', 'Food Banks and Pantries', 'Food Stamps', 'Poverty']
abstract: Many routinely skip meals and take ‘poverty naps’ because they cannot afford groceries. Campus food pantries are helping, but are they enough?
lead_paragraph: In the coming weeks, thousands of college students will walk across a stage and proudly accept their diplomas. Many of them will be hungry.

headline: Golden State’s Klay Thompson Is a Different Kind of Dangerous
abstract: Thompson, the Golden State Warriors’ All-Star guard, is known for his long-range 3-point shooting, but his defense keeps opponents on their heels and bricking shots.
lead_paragraph: Klay Thompson of the Golden State Warriors knows that playing defense in the N.B.A. is difficult. As one of the league’s elite scorers, he causes his share of problems by launching 3-pointers from distant outposts. But he also has to spend about half his time trying to prevent opponents from doing the same.

headline: Secret Venezuela Files Warn About Maduro Confidant
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Money Laundering', 'Cocaine and Crack Cocaine']
abstract: Venezuela’s intelligence agency gathered evidence against one of the country’s most powerful figures, including accusations of drug trafficking and ties to Hezbollah.
lead_paragraph: He is one of the most powerful leaders of the Venezuelan government, a hard-liner who has put down protests, confronted rebels and been a constant presence at the side of Nicolás Maduro, the country’s authoritarian president.

headline: 36 Hours in Melbourne
abstract: How to spend a weekend in this coffee-sipping, culture-loving, boundary-pushing city in southern Australia.
lead_paragraph: Pity Melbourne: After seven years of topping the Economist Intelligence Unit’s most livable city rankings, it was finally displaced last year by another coffee-loving city, Vienna. Despite being nudged down a notch to No. 2, Melburnians aren’t too worried. Though the city is currently grappling with issues related to being such a popular place to live — rapid growth, high property prices, congested roads — the city in the southeastern part of Australia continues to be the country’s capital for all things cultural. There are more festivals than can fit on a calendar; a thriving, boundary-pushing restaurant scene; and a commitment to the arts that will only deepen with the National Gallery of Victoria’s plans to build the largest contemporary art gallery in Australia by 2025. Melbourne may have lost its crown, but it still has its spacious Victorian-era parks, flat whites and famously sunny way of life.

headline: As Chinese Flock to Siberia’s Lake Baikal, Local Russians Growl
abstract: A supposed new era of Sino-Russian friendship is exhibiting strains as a Chinese influx around Lake Baikal stirs old Russian fears of a land grab.
lead_paragraph: LISTVYANKA, Russia — When Andrei Sukhanov saw that the Chinese-owned hotel rising next door was about to obstruct the sweeping view of Lake Baikal from his small, rustic motel, he steeled himself with a shot of vodka, grabbed his chain saw and chopped down eight wooden pillars buttressing the construction.

headline: Still Separate, Still Unequal: Teaching about School Segregation and Educational Inequality
abstract: Although many students learn about the struggles to desegregate schools in the civil rights era, segregation as a current reality is largely absent from the curriculum. This teaching resource uses Times articles and Op-Eds to investigate the issue.
lead_paragraph: Racial segregation in public education has been illegal for 65 years in the United States. Yet American public schools remain largely separate and unequal — with profound consequences for students, especially students of color.

headline: Distracted by Tech While Driving? The Answer May Be More Tech
keywords: ['Driver Distraction and Fatigue', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Voice Recognition Systems', 'Cellular Telephones']
abstract: The most effective safety features may be the systems that are laying the foundation for the autonomous cars of the future.
lead_paragraph: Driving while distracted is nothing new, but new distractions for drivers pop up all the time. While carmakers and tech companies have worked to keep drivers from checking their phones, the most effective safety features may be the technology that is laying the foundation for autonomous cars.

headline: Fighting for the Soul of Islam in Sri Lanka
abstract: After the Easter bombings, I am struggling to understand how violent ideology has taken hold in my Muslim community.
lead_paragraph: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — Two days after the Easter Sunday bomb attacks in Sri Lanka, I met my greengrocer at the Colpetty market, a symbol of the cosmopolitan city that I call home. I have known Ashraff virtually all my life. He did not have his usual half-smile on his face, and when I went up to him to say goodbye, I could see he was troubled.

headline: We Should Worry About How China Uses Apps Like TikTok
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Privacy', 'Censorship', 'Uighurs (Chinese Ethnic Group)', 'Computer Vision', 'Politics and Government', 'Computers and the Internet', '5G (Wireless Communications)']
abstract: Illiberal innovations created for China’s vast surveilled and censored domestic market are increasingly popular overseas.
lead_paragraph: Illiberal innovations created for China’s vast surveilled and censored domestic market are increasingly popular overseas.

headline: Forget ‘Game of Thrones.’ No One Does Violence Like Euripides.
abstract: Two productions in Paris with their roots in the Greek playwright’s works explore the nature of human brutality. But without any CGI effects.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Long-separated siblings looking to avenge their father, an ancient dynasty under threat, savage murders and even a penis chopped off. No, this isn’t the final season of “Game of Thrones” but two plays written nearly 2,500 years ago: Euripides’ “Electra” and “Orestes,” newly staged at the Comédie-Française by the Belgian director Ivo van Hove.

headline: DealBook Briefing: Capitalists Fear a Socialist Revolt
abstract: At the Milken Institute’s annual global conference this week, business leaders shared a concern: a coming backlash against capitalism.
lead_paragraph: Good Thursday. (Want this by email? Sign up here.)

headline: ‘Extremely Wicked, Shockingly Evil and Vile’ Review: Killing Me Softly
abstract: Zac Efron might be the best thing about Joe Berlinger’s strange biopic of the serial killer Ted Bundy. Which is a sentence I never imagined myself writing.
lead_paragraph: Leaning into his hotness with surprising dexterity, Zac Efron plays the notoriously charming serial killer Ted Bundy like someone who has always understood how to weaponize a pretty face. So the problem with the biopic “Extremely Wicked, Shockingly Evil and Vile” isn’t Efron (or that cumbersome title), but his director, Joe Berlinger. Working ostensibly from the viewpoint of Bundy’s longtime girlfriend, Liz Kendall (an excellent Lily Collins), Berlinger never fully commits. Instead, he appears as seduced by Bundy as virtually everyone else in the movie.

headline: ‘Hesburgh’ Review: A Portrait of a Heroic and Scandal-Free Catholic Priest
abstract: A man of the cloth, a man against racism: “Hesburgh” tells the story of a tireless civil rights champion.
lead_paragraph: If you’re Catholic, and have an aunt or other relative who’s expressed agitation that pretty much every movie in which the Church figures nowadays focuses on a scandal, “Hesburgh” may do your relative a world of good. The documentary about the Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, who was president of the University of Notre Dame for 35 years, is a portrait of a man who can be seen as not merely blameless, but genuinely heroic.

headline: ‘The Convent’ Review: Twisted Sisters
abstract: Paul Hyett’s nasty-nunnery tale is a bewildering jumble of real-world evils and otherworldly threats.
lead_paragraph: The director Paul Hyett, who has a lengthy résumé in special makeup effects, appears to have a particular affinity for eyeballs. In “The Convent,” so many of these are gouged, popped or singed that it’s easy to lose count — especially in a movie whose murky plot and even murkier lighting puts a considerable strain on our own.

headline: ‘Ask Dr. Ruth’ Review: Out of the Bedroom and into the Light
abstract: Ryan White’s rose-tinted portrait of Dr. Ruth Westheimer, the irrepressible sex therapist and Holocaust survivor, leaves no room for naysayers.
lead_paragraph: There was a time in the 1980s when Dr. Ruth Westheimer, petite sex guru and irrepressible advocate of democratized pleasure, seemed to be everywhere. In bookstores and on the radio, or perched alongside a squirming Johnny Carson or David Letterman, she thrust the female orgasm to center stage while reassuring men that its achievement didn’t require supersized equipment.

headline: ‘Decade of Fire’ Review: A Documentary Remembers the Blazes That Scorched the Bronx
abstract: This documentary is at its best when showing how the fires affected individuals effectively left to fend for themselves.
lead_paragraph: “Decade of Fire” positions itself as a corrective to the notion that Bronx residents were responsible for the wave of arson that laid siege to the borough in the 1970s. Vivian Vázquez Irizarry, who directed the documentary with Gretchen Hildebran and also narrates, begins with a rejoinder. “We did not burn the South Bronx,” she says. “In fact, we were the ones who saved it.”

headline: ‘Shadow’ Review: A Bleak World Splashed With Red
abstract: Zhang Yimou’s film, set during the “Three Kingdoms” era in Chinese history, features head-spinning palace intrigue and spectacularly inventive violence.
lead_paragraph: After the limp 2017 film “The Great Wall,” the director Zhang Yimou was clearly looking to enact a return to form. With “Shadow,” Zhang has done more than that: He’s created a martial-arts movie landmark, as strong in its performances as it is spectacularly novel in its violence.

headline: ‘El Chicano’ Review: Freeing East Los Angeles With Bloodshed
abstract: In search of a specific Mexican-American identity, Ben Hernandez Bray’s ultraviolent epic follows a masked vigilante who does battle with the city’s gangsters.
lead_paragraph: In the ultraviolent east Los Angeles epic “El Chicano,” a police officer, Diego Hernandez (Raúl Castillo), finds himself at a moral crossroads when he unearths a connection between his late brother, Pedro, and the execution-style killing of local gang members. As Diego dives into Pedro’s past, he enters a punishing street war that quickly becomes painful to watch.

headline: ‘Clara’ Review: Love Means Never Having to Say You’re Starry
abstract: A ruthless empiricist searching for life beyond Earth learns a thing or two about life on the planet.
lead_paragraph: “Clara” cloaks its clichés in astronomy jargon and mood lighting, but in the final analysis this Canadian feature from Akash Sherman is yet another movie about a dying dream woman whose cosmic role is to teach a ruthless empiricist to go with the flow.

headline: ‘Meeting Gorbachev’ Review: Sitting Down With the Last Soviet Leader
abstract: Werner Herzog’s latest documentary is centered on Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who helped bring the Cold War to an end.
lead_paragraph: Geopolitics has never been high on Werner Herzog’s list of concerns, at least in his documentaries. Even when he glances toward current events (“Lessons of Darkness,” “Into the Abyss”), the thrust tends to be philosophical — his interests run more to quixotic quests and humanity’s insignificance in the vastness of nature. That makes him an odd fit to interview Mikhail S. Gorbachev, whose leadership of the Soviet Union helped bring the Cold War to an end.

headline: Julian Assange Appears in Court for U.S. Extradition Hearing
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Extradition', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: Via a video link from prison, the WikiLeaks founder said he did not wish to surrender himself to the U.S. authorities to face a hacking charge.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, appeared in a British court on Thursday for an initial hearing on whether he will be extradited to the United States to face prosecution in connection with one of the most serious leaks of classified material in American history.

headline: Pelosi Accuses Barr of Law-Breaking as Democrats’ War With Him Boils Over
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Attorney General William P. Barr pulled out of a Thursday hearing of the House Judiciary Committee, and he has left House lawmakers who are investigating the president fuming and calculating.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Democrats’ feud with Attorney General William P. Barr boiled over on Thursday, as Speaker Nancy Pelosi accused him of lying to Congress and the Judiciary Committee threatened to hold him in contempt if he did not promptly hand over a complete version of Robert S. Mueller III’s report.

headline: Jacob deGrom and Noah Syndergaard Remind the World What They Can Do
abstract: DeGrom threw seven shutout innings on Wednesday and Syndergaard was even better in a shutout on Thursday. If they have returned to form, the Mets could soar.
lead_paragraph: When Jacob deGrom took the mound against the Cincinnati Reds on Wednesday night, the Mets’ starters had a combined 5.09 earned run average for the season. To put that in context of recent major leaguers, a 5.09 E.R.A. is somewhere between the career marks of Sidney Ponson and Hideki Irabu.

headline: Her Hint for Collecting Like an Artist: Use Instagram
abstract: Zoë Buckman has amassed pieces by creators known and unknown, and she has swapped her own work for that of other artists.
lead_paragraph: The artist Zoë Buckman’s loft-cum-studio in Dumbo delivers a sensory overload of paintings, photography and sketches from around the world.

headline: Tarantino’s ‘Once Upon a Time in Hollywood’ Is Confirmed for Cannes
abstract: “We were afraid the film would not be ready,” said the festival’s artistic director. But Quentin Tarantino, he added, “is a real, loyal and punctual child of Cannes.”
lead_paragraph: Quentin Tarantino’s “Once Upon a Time in Hollywood,” about an actor and his stunt double in the 1960s, will have its world premiere at the Cannes Film Festival this month, the festival announced on Thursday.

lead_paragraph: DENVER — Michael Bennet, the moderate, studious Democratic senator from Colorado known for his work on education and immigration reform, announced his candidacy for president on Thursday.

headline: How Can I Save My Workaholic Boyfriend From Himself?
abstract: Therapy might be the best bet.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been with my boyfriend for a year. Occasionally, he goes into deep panics about his work and cancels plans — and not just with me. He cancels dinners with friends and important doctors’ appointments, holidays with his family and trips we’ve booked months in advance. I love him, and want to be compassionate about his panic and his work. But some plans are important to me. We’re supposed to visit my family soon, and he’s already threatening to cancel. He says: Everything will fall apart if he goes away. What can I do?

headline: ‘The Intruder’ Review: Dennis Quaid as a Homeowner’s Nightmare
abstract: Michael Ealy and Meagan Good get more than they bargained for when they buy their dream house.
lead_paragraph: “The Intruder,” a real-estate-based thriller set in California’s Napa Valley, is more silly than scary. This doesn’t seem to be entirely intentional, and it isn’t altogether unwelcome. The idea of Dennis Quaid popping up in your kitchen in the middle of the night might not exactly be the stuff of nightmares. Quaid, playing a deranged ex-homeowner named Charlie Peck, seems to know this. And the director, Deon Taylor, does too.

headline: Tesla Seeks to Raise $2 Billion in Sale of Stock and Debt
keywords: ['Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Company Reports', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Automobiles', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: The plan, disclosed in a regulatory filing, comes after the carmaker announced a surprisingly sharp quarterly loss.
lead_paragraph: Tesla needs more money. A lot of it.

headline: Following the Money in Residential Real Estate
abstract: Almost half the money spent by New York City home buyers in the first quarter of 2019 went toward the most expensive properties. That wasn’t always the case.
lead_paragraph: Nearly half the money spent on residential real estate in Manhattan during the first quarter of 2019 (45.4 percent, to be exact) was spent on the most expensive homes — those that sold for more than $4 million — according to information collected by Jonathan J. Miller, president of the appraisal firm Miller Samuel.

headline: At 35, Curtis McElhinney, a Journeyman Goalie, Gets His Moment
abstract: The Carolina Hurricanes are on the cusp of sweeping the Islanders behind McElhinney, who has saved 45 of 47 shots after replacing the injured starter.
lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — The cities, in order, read like an inefficient itinerary for a mobile home tour of North America: Calgary, Anaheim, Ottawa, Phoenix, Columbus, Toronto. They are also the teams that employed Curtis McElhinney across his first 10 N.H.L. seasons, without awarding him a playoff start.

headline: Miller Theater Unveils Its 20th Composer Portraits Series
abstract: Its flagship series features Anthony Braxton, Vijay Iyer, Annea Lockwood, Dai Fujikura, Bright Sheng, Caroline Shaw and Oscar Bettison next season.
lead_paragraph: In a career of over five decades, the avant-jazz artist Anthony Braxton has traversed a range of forms and styles. Now concertgoers will get to hear the breadth of his work, which will open the 20th anniversary of the flagship Composer Portraits series at Miller Theater at Columbia University.

headline: By the Book: Ruth Reichl
abstract: The food writer and author, most recently, of the memoir “Save Me the Plums” was 10 when she read Henry Miller. “If it’s over her head, she simply won’t understand it,” her mother said.
lead_paragraph: The food writer and author, most recently, of the memoir “Save Me the Plums” was 10 when she read Henry Miller. “If it’s over her head, she simply won’t understand it,” her mother said.

headline: Democrats Have 20 Spots in the First Debate. There Are Now 21 Candidates.
abstract: Seventeen candidates have already qualified for the first debate. Here is a look at how the party will decide who makes the stage if that number passes 20.
lead_paragraph: During the 2016 presidential primary, leaders of the Democratic National Committee were frequently accused of showing favoritism toward Hillary Clinton over Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont. Perhaps as a result, party officials have tried to make the 2020 primary process appear more inclusive and transparent.

headline: 15 Years Later, PEN World Voices Festival Is Still Trying to Unify the World
abstract: More than 200 writers will convene in New York City next week to discuss the blurred lines between our public and private lives.
lead_paragraph: The novelist Salman Rushdie co-founded the PEN World Voices Festival 15 years ago, when he was president of PEN America, but it has roots in a conference that occurred decades earlier. In 1986, more than 600 prominent writers from around the world, including Rushdie, gathered for a PEN Congress in New York City.

headline: Parents of Babies Too Young to Vaccinate Feel Trapped by Measles Outbreak
abstract: The measles vaccine is not usually given to children until they are a year old. So some new parents are avoiding public places and anti-vaccine friends.
lead_paragraph: TROY, Mich. — Roberta Traini gritted her teeth through the small talk at the Barnes & Noble checkout, grabbed her purchases and hustled her 5-month-old daughter, Gretha, into the chilly April air, where it was safer to breathe.

headline: How to Assess Security Risks While Traveling
keywords: ['Travel Warnings', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Sri Lanka Easter Bombings (April, 2019)']
abstract: While we can’t predict the next crisis, preparing for the worst and taking charge of our own personal security are essential steps.
lead_paragraph: Tourists who researched security conditions in Sri Lanka before the Easter Sunday terror attacks would have found that travel advisories ranked the threat of terrorism as low.

headline: A London Marathon Obstacle Course: Insults and Sewage Trucks
abstract: A volunteer who led a small group of people aiming to complete the race in 7.5 hours said cleanup crews hindered their progress and made unkind comments.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Marathons have long been seen as the ultimate test of speed and stamina. The winner of last Sunday’s event in London, Eliud Kipchoge of Kenya, crossed the finish line in 2 hours 2 minutes 37 seconds — the second-fastest time ever for the 26.2-mile distance.

headline: At Mama’s Noodle House, Two Chefs Do It All
abstract: At this small Chinese restaurant in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, Nan Yi Liang and Jai Kei Sung fold up to 1,000 dumplings a night.
lead_paragraph: At this small Chinese restaurant in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, Nan Yi Liang and Jai Kei Sung fold up to 1,000 dumplings a night.

headline: The American Family Makes This Country Great, and It’s in Danger
keywords: ['Family Separation Policy (US Immigration)', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Families and Family Life', 'Children and Childhood', 'Immigration Detention', 'Deportation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals']
abstract: President Trump’s stance on legal and undocumented immigrants could have devastating results.
lead_paragraph: Few of the Trump administration’s policies were as universally reviled by Americans across the country as the family separation policy at the border. Yet many Americans would be surprised to learn that the heartbreaking images of children being torn from their parents’ arms are playing out, often invisibly, in communities in this country, posing a severe threat to millions of American children and their families.

headline: The Thin Line Between Surgery and Mutilation
keywords: ['Intersex', 'Women and Girls', 'Female Genital Mutilation', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: There’s a lot of overlap between surgery on intersex infants and female genital mutilation. So why do we view them so differently?
lead_paragraph: Last month, many were up in arms about the news that the Justice Department would not defend a federal prohibition on female genital mutilation that was thrown out by a lower court last fall. On Twitter, Hillary Clinton called the decision “outrageous”; hundreds seconded her tweet with words of disgust.

headline: Just Like Home: Freshly Folded Dumplings in Brooklyn
abstract: At Mama’s Noodle House in Bensonhurst, the line between kitchen and dining room isn’t always clear.
lead_paragraph: There is a point at which a restaurant with an open kitchen becomes more kitchen than restaurant, and diners feel more like lucky house guests than paying customers. To conjure this effect, fine-dining establishments may send people home with a ribbon-tied Ball jar of quirkily flavored granola. Mama’s Noodle House, a small Chinese restaurant in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, does it with five rice cookers of various models and an expandable dining table that moonlights as a dumpling-folding station.

headline: Jack Dorsey Is Gwyneth Paltrow for Silicon Valley
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'Saunas and Sweat Lodges']
abstract: The Twitter chief executive is tech’s foremost manfluencer, guiding his followers toward optimum cognitive performance. Or, at least, hunger.
lead_paragraph: Young men are staggering around, hungry for days. They are throwing themselves into ice baths and cryotherapy pods. There are not enough beds at the silent vegan meditation centers to accommodate them. They need more near-infrared bulbs.

headline: Les Murray, Australia’s Unofficial Poet Laureate, Is Dead at 80
keywords: ['Poetry and Poets', 'Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Deaths (Obituaries)']
abstract: A prolific poet who some said deserved a Nobel Prize, he courted controversy and was always, his biographer said, “on the side of the outcast.”
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Les Murray, an Australian poet with an international reputation and an extraordinary intellect whose verse ruminated on death, his native bushland and his own turbulent life, died on Monday in Taree, New South Wales. He was 80.

headline: From Clay Tablets to Smartphones: 5,000 Years of Writing
abstract: The act of writing always seems to be under threat from technology, yet it manages to adapt and survive. An exhibition at the British Library shows how.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The writing’s on the wall, we’re told. Whether it was Johannes Gutenberg’s printing press in the 15th century, the invention of the typewriter 300 years later, or the emoji of today’s smartphones, the act of writing seems to be forever on the precipice of extinction, without quite falling off.

headline: Tinder Wants In on Your Music Festival Meet-Cute
abstract: The dating app has a new feature to help you find a mate in a sea of flower crowns.
lead_paragraph: Tinder on Thursday announced a new feature called Festival Mode, which will allow users to identify fellow festivalgoers before they descend on Governors Ball, Bonnaroo and Firefly, among other music events. All the better to exchange flower crowns, swap band recommendations and do all the other innocent, happy things that people tend to do together at music festivals.

headline: Film Club: ‘A Kiss, Deferred’
abstract: How might it feel to live through a conflict that disrupts your way of life?
lead_paragraph: How might it feel to live through a conflict that disrupts your way of life?

headline: The Prayer at the Heart of a ‘Quintessentially French’ Opera
abstract: Yannick Nézet-Séguin, the Metropolitan Opera’s music director, discusses a passage from Poulenc’s “Dialogues des Carmélites,” which returns this week.
lead_paragraph: When Yannick Nézet-Séguin learned a few years ago that he would be the next music director of the Metropolitan Opera, he thought about works he was especially eager to conduct. Two came to mind: Debussy’s “Pelléas et Mélisande” and Poulenc’s “Dialogues des Carmélites.”

headline: A Graphic Novel That Answers a Child’s Question About Being Biracial
abstract: In his Graphic Content column, Ed Park looks at Mira Jacob’s “Good Talk,” about her American identity, as well as Bill Griffith’s “Nobody’s Fool,” an origin story set on the freak show circuit.
lead_paragraph: For a person of color in America, the term person of color can be both useful and divisive, at once a form of solidarity and a badge of alienation. There’s a flattening effect, too: A multitude of ethnicities and cultures, with their own color-coded nuances, get crammed into the initials P.O.C.

headline: Trump Won’t Nominate Stephen Moore for Fed Board
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Women and Girls', 'Sexual Harassment', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Mr. Moore, a conservative commentator, appeared unlikely to win Senate confirmation after several Republican lawmakers raised concerns about his past writings denigrating women.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Thursday that he would not nominate Stephen Moore for a seat on the Federal Reserve board, the second time in a month that concerns over a potential nominee’s treatment of women have torpedoed Mr. Trump’s attempt to place a loyalist at the Fed.

headline: Staking Out Battle Lines, House Votes to Keep U.S. in Paris Climate Pact
keywords: ['United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The House passed a bill on Thursday that would block President Trump from quitting the Paris Agreement on climate change.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House passed a bill on Thursday that would block President Trump from abandoning the Paris Agreement on climate change and require his administration to devise a plan to cut America’s greenhouse gas emissions.

headline: Bill Barr’s Perverse Theory of Justice
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Attorneys General', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)', 'Iran-Contra Affair', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)']
abstract: In America, no one is above the law — except the president and everyone who does wrong in his name.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, when Attorney General William Barr testified before the Senate Judiciary Committee about the Mueller report, he addressed lawmakers more as if he were a member of President Trump’s legal team than as the nation’s chief law enforcement officer. Barr framed Trump’s actions as fully justifiable, even arguing that if the president feels an investigation is unfounded, he “does not have to sit there constitutionally and allow it to run its course.”

headline: Teenagers in The Times: April 2019
abstract: Our roundup of the news stories and features about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com.
lead_paragraph: Here is the April 2019 edition of Teenagers in The Times. This roundup of news and feature stories about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com appears on the first Thursday of each month during the school year.

headline: Elizabeth Warren’s Campaign, ‘Based on Ideas,’ Bets on Iowa
abstract: Ms. Warren has hired about 50 people in Iowa, giving her a head start at organizing for next year’s caucuses. But it’s a strategy loaded with risk.
lead_paragraph: WEST DES MOINES, Iowa — It was game time at the “Persist Party.”

headline: Review: In ‘Dead to Me’ on Netflix, Widows Make the Best BFFs
abstract: Christina Applegate and Linda Cardellini star in a dark comedy-mystery as women who form a bond based on bereavement, guilt and righteous anger.
lead_paragraph: This week’s case study in the anxieties of contemporary television: “Dead to Me,” a new series on Netflix starring Christina Applegate and Linda Cardellini as widows who meet cute at a grief support group.

headline: Maduro Speaks to Troops, Trying to Discredit Guaidó’s Call for Mutiny
abstract: The appearance by President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela appeared intended to further contradict assertions of authority by Juan Guaidó, the opposition leader.
lead_paragraph: Venezuela’s president sought to strengthen his image as the undisputed commander of the armed forces on Thursday, mustering troops in a televised show of authority days after the opposition tried to incite a military mutiny that fizzled within hours.

headline: On a Coastline With 1,200 Dead Dolphins, Fishermen and Conservationists Clash
abstract: More common dolphins have washed up dead on France’s Atlantic Coast since January than in all of 2017 or 2018. Scientists blame fishing. Fishermen are pushing back.
lead_paragraph: LA ROCHELLE, France — At dawn on a recent Saturday, the crew of the fishing trawler L’Arlequin II pulled their cone-shaped net up from the Bay of Biscay, and found the usual catch crammed into the bottom: hundreds of bass.

headline: Interior Dept. Loosens Offshore-Drilling Safety Rules Dating From Deepwater Horizon
keywords: ['Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Environment', 'Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The loosening of regulations on offshore drilling equipment has been a been a key piece of President Trump’s efforts to ease restrictions on fossil fuel companies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration on Thursday made public its rollback of a major offshore-drilling safety regulation, significantly weakening an Obama-era rule that was put in place after the 2010 Deepwater Horizon explosion in the Gulf of Mexico, which killed 11 people and sent 4.9 million barrels of oil gushing into the sea, causing the worst oil spill in American history.

headline: ‘Nobody Is Above the Law’: House Democrats Are Furious With Barr
abstract: Representative Jerrold Nadler, the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, threatened to hold Attorney General William P. Barr in contempt of Congress after he did not appear at a hearing. Speaker Nancy Pelosi said that he lied to Congress. “That’s a crime,” she said.
lead_paragraph: Representative Jerrold Nadler, the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, threatened to hold Attorney General William P. Barr in contempt of Congress after he did not appear at a hearing. Speaker Nancy Pelosi said that he lied to Congress. “That’s a crime,” she said.

headline: Danny Ainge, Boston Celtics President, Has Mild Heart Attack
abstract: Ainge, 60, also had a heart attack in 2009. The Celtics said he is expected to make a full recovery.
lead_paragraph: Danny Ainge, the president of basketball operations for the Boston Celtics, had a mild heart attack Tuesday night in Milwaukee, the team said.

headline: F.B.I. Sent Investigator Posing as Assistant to Meet With Trump Aide in 2016
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The use of the investigator in an operation aimed at a campaign shows the alarm in the F.B.I. as officials uncovered the scope of Russia’s 2016 election interference.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The conversation at a London bar in September 2016 took a strange turn when the woman sitting across from George Papadopoulos, a Trump campaign adviser, asked a direct question: Was the Trump campaign working with Russia?

headline: U.S. Women’s World Cup Roster Stocked With Experience in the Tournament
abstract: Carli Lloyd, Alex Morgan, Megan Rapinoe, Tobin Heath, Becky Sauerbrunn and Kelley O’Hara will all be part of the team in France.
lead_paragraph: U.S. Soccer named its roster for this summer’s Women’s World Cup on Thursday, but in doing so Coach Jill Ellis essentially acknowledged that her best hope for retaining the title is to trust many of the same players to repeat the feat.

headline: How Right, Left and Center Reacted to the Barr Testimony
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates']
abstract: Writers across the political spectrum responded to Attorney General William P. Barr’s appearance before the Senate Judiciary Committee.
lead_paragraph: The political news cycle is fast, and keeping up can be overwhelming. Trying to find differing perspectives worth your time is even harder. That’s why we have scoured the internet for writing from across the political spectrum that you might not have seen.

headline: ‘Long Shot’ Review: Charlize Theron and Seth Rogen Give Good Heart
abstract: The improbably yet perfectly paired stars play old friends who unexpectedly find love in this charming (and a bit vulgar) romantic comedy.
lead_paragraph: “Long Shot” isn’t going to save the romantic comedy, but it’s an adrenaline shot of pure pleasure to the genre’s failing heart. The outline is familiar: Two people meet, retreat and then circle each other, all while talking and talking. The romantic comedy turns on people who fit together — in bed, on the dance floor — but also talk to each other, exchanging words that stop flowing and faltering only with a culminating kiss and teasing fade-out. The difference here is that unlike a lot of romances, the woman retains her power and identity, and that’s how the movie likes it.

headline: Hillary Clinton Blasts Trump, Barr and Parts of Mueller Report
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: In an interview Wednesday on “The Rachel Maddow Show” Mrs. Clinton warned of continuing Russian efforts to interfere in U.S. elections.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton sharply criticized Attorney General William P. Barr, President Trump, members of the Republican Party and some findings of the Mueller report on Wednesday night in a wide-ranging interview in which she warned of continuing Russian efforts to interfere in United States elections.

headline: Watch ‘Boyz N the Hood’ Free at the Tribeca Film Festival
abstract: The festival will honor John Singleton, who died Monday, by playing his seminal debut feature.
lead_paragraph: The Tribeca Film Festival has added a free screening of John Singleton’s breakout movie, “Boyz N the Hood,” to its lineup. The filmmaker died Monday after suffering a stroke.

headline: What Is a Leak? U.K. Defense Secretary’s Firing in Huawei Case Is in a Murky Zone
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The government says Gavin Williamson committed a grievous security breach. He says he did no such thing. The way the British news media work, both are possible.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After dismissing her defense secretary on accusations he leaked sensitive information, Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain declared the matter “closed,” and on Thursday her government insisted that the police need not investigate one of the most serious security breaches in recent memory.

headline: U.S. Airstrikes and Raids Killed 120 Civilians in 2018, Pentagon Says
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The number of civilian casualties investigated by the Defense Department is far lower than what watchdog groups have also reported.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The American military killed 120 civilians in strikes, raids and firefights across two continents in 2018, the Pentagon said Thursday — a far lower number than what watchdog groups have reported.

headline: Why Is This Ostrich Wearing an Extra Set of Wings?
abstract: Scientists took a creative approach to studying how dinosaurs evolved the flying abilities of modern birds.
lead_paragraph: A young ostrich sprints down a path at a Chinese farm. His neck bobs, his legs pump — and the artificial wings attached to his back flap up and down.

headline: How Will Satan & Adam Play in 2019?
keywords: ['Blues Music', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: An interracial blues duo born in 1980s Harlem was a symbol of harmony in a tense time. But times have changed.
lead_paragraph: “I can’t believe how many white people are in Harlem now,” Adam Gussow said. He was strolling around the neighborhood, marveling at how much the place had changed since he was a Columbia University grad-school dropout in the 1980s. “I was the only white guy in Harlem at the time. I just saw a white guy jogging. You never used to see that.”

headline: Leana Wen of Planned Parenthood Wants to Tackle the ‘Fundamental Unfairness in Our System’
abstract: Dr. Wen immigrated to the U.S. at 7, graduated college at 18, became a Rhodes scholar and is now at the front lines of the fight over women’s health care rights.
lead_paragraph: When Leana Wen became president of Planned Parenthood last year, she had big shoes to fill. Her predecessor, Cecile Richards, emerged as a major voice on issues involving public health and women’s rights during her 12 years in the job.

headline: On Being Young, Gay and Addicted in the 1970s
abstract: “The Light Years,” a memoir by the artist Chris Rush, evokes his troubled youth in a wealthy Catholic family in New Jersey and his search for acceptance in the mountains of the Southwest.
lead_paragraph: The Light Years By Chris Rush

headline: Review: Two Lives and Two Playwrights ‘Entangled’ by Gunfire
abstract: Charly Evon Simpson and Gabriel Jason Dean collaborated on a play that finds scant healing for a guilty brother and a grieving mother.
lead_paragraph: Bradley and Greta don’t seem to have much in common. He’s a white man with a nondescript office job, living in Brooklyn with his boyfriend Orion. She’s a black woman trying to “climb a corporate ladder” while raising her little daughter Astrid.

headline: Tiger Woods to Receive Presidential Medal of Freedom on Monday
abstract: After winning the Masters last month, his first major in a decade, Woods will become the fourth golfer to be given the nation’s highest civilian honor.
lead_paragraph: Tiger Woods will be awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom by President Trump on Monday, the White House said Thursday.

headline: Florida to Let Teachers Carry Guns. Will Black Students Pay the Price?
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Parkland, Fla, Shooting (2018)', 'State Legislatures', 'Gun Control']
abstract: The Florida House sent a measure allowing teachers to be armed to the governor after a long and emotional debate about the intersection of gun laws and race.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The outcome of the vote in the Florida State House this week was a foregone conclusion: A proposal to allow teachers to carry firearms in school would easily win approval.

headline: F.D.A. Won’t Ban Sales of Textured Breast Implants Linked to Cancer
keywords: ['Breasts', 'Implants', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Plastic Surgery', "Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma", 'your-feed-science', 'your-feed-healthcare']
abstract: Many other countries have already banned the products. But the U.S. agency said the risk was still low, despite repeated requests from women and doctors that the implants be removed from the market.
lead_paragraph: A type of breast implant linked to a rare cancer can still be sold in the United States, even though it has been banned in many other countries, the Food and Drug Administration said on Thursday.

headline: What Interests You Most in The Times Right Now? Why?
abstract: Wander through The Times and tell us what gets your attention, whether an article, photo, graph, video, or podcast. Then, as practice for our Summer Reading Contest, tell us why here.
lead_paragraph: Every day in our Student Opinion forum we pick the articles and ask you what you think about them. Now, we’re flipping the script and asking you to tell us what we should read.

headline: To Combat Climate Change, Start From the Ground Up (With Dirt)
abstract: Dirt is dead, but soil is alive — packed with nutrients and boasting properties that keep carbon out of the atmosphere.
lead_paragraph: Wendy MacNaughton is a graphic journalist based in San Francisco. You can find her via website and Instagram.

headline: Military Judge in Trial of Sept. 11 Suspects Will Step Aside
abstract: The development could further delay the case against five men accused of directing, training or assisting the hijackers who killed nearly 3,000 people.
lead_paragraph: This article was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.

headline: Disability Didn’t End Their Athletic Dreams. It Started Them.
abstract: At a gym in Queens, Donahue Fields is training people and laying the foundation for a new sport: wheelchair boxing.
lead_paragraph: You’re boxing in a wheelchair, and you get into a vulnerable position that you want to get out of. Think about it. The only way to move away from the blows is to lower your hands to the wheels, leaving your head unprotected.

headline: Bank of England Foresees Faster Economic Growth
abstract: Britain’s central bank said it might need to raise its benchmark interest rate more than once over next three years.
lead_paragraph: The Bank of England on Thursday raised its growth forecast for the British economy through the next three years, and said it might need to raise its benchmark interest rate more than once over that period to control inflation.

abstract: Readers lament that the party is overshadowing the parsha (Torah portion).

abstract: The pet name “bae,” the gender-neutral pronoun “ze” and the verbal thumbs up “ok” are among the words newly approved for international Scrabble play.
lead_paragraph: The official international Scrabble dictionary has updated its list of approved words for the first time since 2015, opening up an additional 2,800 words to players at tournaments and at home.

headline: A Very Modern Waste of Tax Dollars
keywords: ['Corporate Taxes', 'E-Commerce', 'Sales and Excise Taxes', 'Relocation of Business']
abstract: In California, the rise of online retail is supersizing a corporate tax incentive. Banning it would benefit everyone (except corporations).
lead_paragraph: When Californians place an online order with Best Buy, they pay the company and they pay a state sales tax. What the receipt doesn’t say is that Best Buy gets some of the sales tax, too.

headline: The ‘Home of the Giants’ Is for You, Too
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Camps and Camping', 'Hikes and Hiking', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: In Norway, camping in the wild is a right.
lead_paragraph: JOTUNHEIMEN NATIONAL PARK, Norway — The Besseggen ridge juts from the earth as a curved spine of sharp, dark-gray stone and carves its way between two blue lakes in Jotunheimen, one of Norway’s many spectacular, wild national parks. “Jotunheimen” translates as “home of the giants,” and everything here is oversize, including the lakes. They are separated only by a narrow slice of the ridge yet have very distinct colors: Gjende is a long sweep of aquamarine; Bessvatnet is a dark royal blue.

headline: What Watergate Prosecutors Had That Mueller Didn’t
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Watergate Affair', 'Law and Legislation', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Impeachment']
abstract: In the Trump-Russia investigation, the special counsel did not have the leverage of physical evidence.
lead_paragraph: I served as an assistant special prosecutor on the Watergate Special Prosecution Force, and I have been frequently struck by the similarities between the investigations of Presidents Nixon and Trump. Both involved property theft from the Democratic National Committee and resulted in the criminal convictions of individuals close to the president. Presidents Nixon and Trump repeatedly lied to the American people to cover up their conduct, and the head prosecutor in each case chose not to indict a sitting president but rather to provide Congress with a “road map” for impeachment should Congress choose to pursue it.

headline: ‘One of the Rarest Things in Baseball’: Noah Syndergaard Does It All
abstract: Syndergaard became the first pitcher in 36 years to hit a home run and throw a complete-game shutout in a 1-0 victory as the Mets beat the Cincinnati Reds.
lead_paragraph: Noah Syndergaard believed he had already reached rock bottom.

headline: After Semenya Ruling, Sports Federations Ponder What’s Next
abstract: The decision on intersex athletes was narrow. But for sports federations, new complaints of unfair advantages seem likely.
lead_paragraph: “This opens Pandora’s box.”

headline: Top Executives of Insys, an Opioid Company, Are Found Guilty of Racketeering
keywords: ['Pain-Relieving Drugs', 'Opioids and Opiates', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Racketeering and Racketeers', 'your-feed-health']
abstract: The defendants were accused of conspiring to bribe doctors to prescribe a fentanyl-based painkiller and misleading insurers about patients’ need for the drug.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — A federal jury on Thursday found the top executives of Insys Therapeutics, a company that sold a fentanyl-based painkiller, guilty of racketeering charges in a rare criminal prosecution that blamed corporate officials for contributing to the nation’s opioid epidemic.

headline: ‘A Fortunate Man’ Review: A Danish Engineer Strives for Success
abstract: Adapted from the Danish author Henrik Pontoppidan’s turn-of-the-20th-century novel “Lucky Per,” the film hoists subtext so high that it surpasses text.
lead_paragraph: The title “A Fortunate Man” has a double edge, as the movie, whose characters rarely fail to explain their motives and circumstances, never tires of reminding you. The screenwriting, adapted from the Danish author Henrik Pontoppidan’s turn-of-the-20th-century novel “Lucky Per,” hoists subtext so high that it surpasses text. Walk through the room once an hour, and you’ll be good. (The film is now streaming on Netflix.)

headline: Woody Allen Pitched a Memoir. Publishers Weren’t Interested.
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Books and Literature', 'Movies', '#MeToo Movement', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: Executives at several houses said they passed on the material and in some cases declined to read it because of controversies surrounding him.
lead_paragraph: Woody Allen has been largely shunned by Hollywood. Celebrities who once vied for roles in his films now say they regret working with him. Amazon has backed out of a multimovie distribution deal with him.

headline: Infant Dies, Three Migrants Feared Dead in Raft Tragedy on Rio Grande
abstract: Migrant children were missing after a raft overturned in fast-moving water in the Rio Grande on the Texas border.
lead_paragraph: [Read the latest edition of Crossing the Border,  a limited-run newsletter about life where the United States and Mexico meet. Sign up here to receive the next issue in your inbox.]

headline: What Students Are Saying About: Online Learning, Family Vacations and Moving to a New Home
abstract: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts — and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
lead_paragraph: This week, we have comments from teenagers around the country who weighed in on an online education program from Silicon Valley, shared their favorite family vacations and told us what it’s like to move to a new home.

headline: Facebook Bars Alex Jones, Louis Farrakhan and Others From Its Services
abstract: The move, which critics said was a long time coming, is an escalation of the social media company’s enforcement of its content policies.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — After years of wavering about how to handle the extreme voices populating its platform, Facebook on Thursday evicted seven of its most controversial users — many of whom are conservatives — immediately inflaming the debate about the power and accountability of large technology companies.

headline: Baltimore’s Mayor, Catherine Pugh, Resigns Amid Children’s Book Scandal
keywords: ['Mayors', 'Politics and Government', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The resignation came days after the City Council proposed amending the charter to make it possible to remove Ms. Pugh and amid a widening scandal involving a book deal worth $500,000.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of mounting pressure, Mayor Catherine Pugh of Baltimore resigned on Thursday amid a widening scandal involving hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of children’s books that she wrote and that the University of Maryland Medical System paid for while she was serving on its board of directors.

headline: Parasites Infect These Beetles. It Might Be a Good Thing.
abstract: The insects digest more decaying wood when hosting nematodes, potentially benefiting the whole ecosystem.
lead_paragraph: Leishmaniasis parasites eat human flesh. Cordyceps fungi lead ants to suicide. Toxoplasma gondii eliminate a mouse’s fear of cats. And a barnacle called Sacculina carcini castrates crabs, roots itself into their bodies and brains and transforms them into walking zombie slaves that care for the parasite’s brood as if it were their own.

headline: At Frieze New York, Islands of Daring
abstract: Don’t be daunted by the fair’s nearly 200 booths. Our critics have done the walking and have found the standouts.
lead_paragraph: Getting into this year’s Frieze Art Fair on Randalls Island will cost you $57, plus the round trip on the ferry. But that’s nothing compared to what it cost nearly 200 galleries to exhibit there. And so dealers have made the reasonable decision to bring a little of everything that sells — which may account for the conservative vibe. That said, there are many islands of daring, including special sections focused on solo presentations, small galleries, the influential gallery JAM and virtual reality. We sampled them all — along with the mainland fairs that are part of Frieze Week. Our art critics Martha Schwendener and Will Heinrich pick a handful of the best booths under Frieze New York’s big tent.

headline: Tefaf Brings Masterpieces (and Tulips) to the Armory
abstract: The Dutch art fair, focusing on modern and contemporary art and design, has cemented itself as a key appointment on New York’s art calendar.
lead_paragraph: Art fairs used to be principally trade shows for specialist audiences, and few were more established and exclusive than the European Fine Art Fair — which each March lures museum directors and deep-pocketed connoisseurs to Maastricht, in the southern tip of the Netherlands. Now, fairs constitute a year-round global festival of commerce, chitchat and champagne sponsorship, and Tefaf has established a pair of smaller New York spinoffs: a fall edition focused on older art, and a spring show with a more modern orientation.

headline: ‘Hi, Merce!’

headline: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Before April recedes too far into the rearview, let’s pause a moment to appreciate a month that gave us cause — as if we needed it — to celebrate both earth and verse. Whether you wanted a book for Earth Day (April 22) or for National Poetry Month (the whole darn month), Brian Teare’s “Doomstead Days” might have served: A collection of poems composed while walking, it honors and mourns the changing landscapes it encounters throughout. If that whets your appetite for more poetry, you should definitely read Morgan Parker’s “Magical Negro,” which cements her place as one of the smartest, liveliest, most accomplished young poets working today. Or if it fires you up to read more about the environment and what we’re doing to it, Nathaniel Rich’s “Losing Earth: A Climate History” (which started as an article for The Times Magazine) spins a bleak and gripping narrative about how we’ve reached this point. SMH, as the kids say online. That’s short for “shaking my head,” but in my house we thought for a long time it meant “so much hate.” In this case, both meanings apply.

lead_paragraph: BORDERS & BELONGING at Public School 10 (May 4, 2-4 p.m.). Books can build bridges even when politicians want to erect walls. This Brooklyn presentation, recommended for ages 9 to 12, features the children’s author Matt de la Peña, who is the American son of a Mexican father, and New York State Assemblywoman Catalina Cruz, who was born in Colombia and now represents a district in Queens. De la Peña, whose works include the young-adult novel “Mexican WhiteBoy” and the Newbery Medal-winning picture book “Last Stop on Market Street,” will talk about his heritage and writing, while Cruz will relate her experiences under the Obama administration’s policy Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals. Then Jennifer Szalai, a book critic for The New York Times, will moderate a discussion on immigration, inclusiveness and the unifying power of storytelling.ps10.org

headline: These Smart Devices Protect Your Home While You’re on Vacation
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Travel and Vacations', 'your-feed-wirecutter']
abstract: Take these steps to protect your home from mishaps and intruders when you leave for vacation.
lead_paragraph: It was at our mortgage closing, when the seller received an eye-popping $900 final water bill, that I first developed FOGA: The Fear of Going Away. Apparently, when they vacated the house, a couple of running toilets and a leaky faucet had gone undetected, draining more than 47,000 gallons in a single month — about eight times more than normal. As with the wisdom about liberty, it seemed the price of homeownership would be eternal vigilance.

headline: Marilyn Stasio Gets Cozy With Some Unlikely Heroines — and a Hit Man
abstract: This week’s Crime column features a mom who runs a spy operation and a female medical student in 19th-century Edinburgh. Also a hit man turned P.I.
lead_paragraph: I nominate Kate Moore, the protagonist of Chris Pavone’s sizzling thriller THE PARIS DIVERSION (Crown, $27), for patron saint of working wives and mothers everywhere. Kate is the on-call parent of two rambunctious young boys, Ben and Jake, the problem-solving wife of a high-risk husband, Dexter, and the boss of the Paris substation of a clandestine American spy operation. On top of all that, she’s expected to be the perfect expat mom, a cut above those other expat wives with their “aggressive parenting, fanatical nesting, competitive entertaining.” It’s almost a relief when a suicide bomber strapped with explosives turns up at the Place Vendôme and gives Kate an excuse to get out of the house and back into the game.

Then came the picture of two saucy showgirls that she snapped surreptitiously from the ladies’ loo in a London pub in 1963. It landed on front pages around the world.

What comes next was even less clear than before.

headline: Why Does Apple Control Its Competitors?
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Wireless Communications', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Regulators should take a close look at the iPhone App Store.
lead_paragraph: Of the 17 most popular screen-time and parental-control apps in the App Store, 11 have been removed or restricted by Apple. The app makers believe they are being punished for competing with Apple’s own screen-time control tools, or worse, for weaning people off Apple devices. Many of the apps had more stringent controls than Apple’s in-house alternatives. Apple says that the applications — specifically, the parental-control apps — were removed because of their use of Mobile Device Management, a technology that gave third parties access to information such as “user location, app use, email accounts, camera permissions and browsing history.” In other words, Apple says it removed the apps to protect the privacy of the children and parents who installed them.

headline: U.S.-China Trade Deal Unlikely to Address Cybertheft or Subsidies
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States Economy', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Intellectual Property', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'United States International Relations', 'Industrial Espionage']
abstract: China has pushed back on addressing key issues like cybertheft and subsidies in the context of the trade talks, officials from the U.S. Chamber of Commerce said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Trade negotiations between the United States and China are entering the final stage, but a deal is expected to fall short of addressing several key Trump administration goals, including combating Chinese cybertheft and state subsidies at various levels of the Chinese government, officials from a leading American business group said on Thursday.

headline: The Revolt of the Democratic Elites
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: And the surprising strength of the rank and file.
lead_paragraph: Both of our major political parties are undergoing fundamental disruption, but the disruption is coming from different directions. The Republican Party has been disrupted from the bottom. In 2016, the educated Republican elites were happy to embrace conventional Republican themes. It was the Republican base that was fed up and wanted Trump — something completely different.

headline: Short Books for Kids That Make a Big Impact
abstract: In refreshingly brief new novels, kids solve family mysteries, save younger siblings and help a grandparent break out of a hospital.
lead_paragraph: Books for middle-grade readers can suffer the same affliction as all too many older-kid and grown-up books: bombastic, bloated, adverb-crammed. Sometimes an economical, minimalist book — like these three — is exactly what a youthful reader needs in this amped-up world.

headline: Peter Mayhew, Actor Behind Chewbacca’s Mask in ‘Star Wars,’ Dies at 74
abstract: Mr. Mayhew played Han Solo’s menacing-seeming yet cuddly sidekick and co-pilot in the original “Star Wars” trilogy and two later films in the franchise.
lead_paragraph: Peter Mayhew, the British-born actor best known for portraying the gentle giant Chewbacca in the “Star Wars” movie franchise, died on Tuesday at his home in North Texas. He was 74.
