headline: To Contain Iran, Trump’s Newest Line in the Sand Looks a Lot Like Obama’s
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Embracing a one-year “breakout” period — a time limit on Iran’s ability to make fuel for a nuclear bomb — was at the heart of the 2015 accord that the U.S. left in May 2018.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Pressed this week to define President Trump’s goals in escalating military and economic pressure on Iran, one of his top foreign policy aides ticked through a familiar list: End the country’s support for terrorism, stop its missile launches and then, most important, keep Iran more than a year away from the capability to build a nuclear weapon.

headline: Steven Mnuchin Refuses to Comply With Subpoena for Trump’s Tax Returns
keywords: ['Federal Taxes (US)', 'Trump Tax Returns', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: The rejection by the Treasury secretary is most likely the last move before the fight heads to court.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin on Friday refused to comply with a congressional subpoena to hand over President Trump’s tax returns, a move that is likely to be the final step before the matter heads to the courts.

headline: Here Come the Brides: A Free-Spirited Fictional Wedding
abstract: Leah Hager Cohen’s novel “Strangers and Cousins” uses a vibrant, anarchic family wedding to explore the way change can be both celebrated and feared.
lead_paragraph: STRANGERS AND COUSINS By Leah Hager Cohen

headline: What Trump Got Wrong on the Investigations Into Michael Flynn
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)']
abstract: The president said he could not have known Mr. Flynn was under investigation. But Mr. Flynn himself revealed it to a top Trump aide, and others warned Mr. Trump about him.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump suggested on Twitter on Friday that he would have fired Michael T. Flynn as an adviser sooner had he known Mr. Flynn was under federal investigation.

headline: Singing the Praises of ‘Big Business’
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Economy', 'Corporate Social Responsibility', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Tyler Cowen’s new book delivers a “love letter” to capitalism, a system he argues is better than all the rest.
lead_paragraph: BIG BUSINESS A Love Letter to an American Anti-Hero By Tyler Cowen

headline: What Justin Trudeau Doesn’t Regret in the SNC-Lavalin Affair
abstract: This week’s Canada Letter features excerpts from The Times’s recent interview with Canada’s prime minister, whose political fortunes have fallen.
lead_paragraph: Last month I sat down with Prime Minister Justin Trudeau for an extended interview, the first since his government had been rocked by the resignations and political turmoil created by its handling of SNC-Lavalin’s criminal prosecution.

headline: Of a Kind: John Derian’s Miniature Homes
abstract: The home-goods designer picked up the first one 25 years ago, at the Chelsea flea market in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: The home-goods designer picked up the first one 25 years ago, at the Chelsea flea market in Manhattan.

headline: You’re Not Alone When You’re on Google
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'Mobile Applications', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing']
abstract: We know that. But the “privacy paradox” means we still act like we are.
lead_paragraph: At first blush, it seems safe to say that most of us harbor inconsistent — if not neurotically contradictory — notions about our personal privacy.

headline: T Suggests: Miniature Houses, Dresses Made From Russian Scarves and More
abstract: A roundup of things our editors — and a few contributors — are excited about in a given week.
lead_paragraph: The newest show at New York’s Yancey Richardson Gallery displays the American Pop artist Claes Oldenburg’s iconic food sculptures, but with a twist: Here, the artist Sharon Core displays photographs of her edible re-creations of Oldenburg’s painted plaster “Hamburger with Pickle and Tomato” (1960) and “Giant Ice Cream Cone, Lying” (1960).

headline: Thomas Nozkowski, Painter of Bold (if Small) Abstractions, Dies at 75
abstract: Mr. Nozkowski rejected the grandiose Abstract Expressionism of his youth and created modest, colorful and self-contained abstract works with his own stamp.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Nozkowski, whose small, insistent, richly hued abstractions upended the heroic scale of postwar New York art and helped push painting in a more accessible, personal and wryly self-aware direction, died on May 9 in Rhinebeck, N.Y. He was 75.

headline: Trump’s Financial Disclosure Form: Five Takeaways
abstract: The president’s family business had a down year in 2018. A close look at the numbers shows how politics, among other factors, is affecting his hotels, golf courses and other properties.
lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump became president, he left his eldest sons in charge of his company, with a mandate to continue expanding the family’s business and brand — which they said at the time was “the hottest it has ever been.”

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

abstract: Lauren Salzman, a senior member of the group, described how women would array themselves naked in front of the group’s founder as he sat in a chair and lectured.

headline: Bobbie Raymond, 80, Visionary on Racially Integrated Housing, Dies
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Segregation and Desegregation', 'Deaths (Obituaries)']
abstract: In Oak Park, bordering Chicago’s West Side, she fought for a fair housing law and helped curb white flight using a strategy that became a model.
lead_paragraph: Bobbie Raymond, whose visionary strategy for curbing white flight from her suburban Chicago village was embraced as a national model for racial integration in housing, died on May 7 in Chicago. She was 80.

headline: Mel Gibson’s ‘Rothchild’ Movie? There Are More Bizarre Films for Sale at Cannes
abstract: The Cannes Film Festival is also a marketplace where merchants flaunt movies that haven’t been made yet, in the hope of drawing media attention and buyers.
lead_paragraph: CANNES, France — Becket is the illegitimate son of a wealthy New York dynasty: His mother, an heiress from a family of financiers, eloped with a jazz musician. Becket feels entitled to a share of the family riches, but his evil grandfather is standing in the way.

headline: Morrison Wins in Australian Election, Confounding Pollsters
abstract: The victory for Prime Minister Scott Morrison upset analysts’ expectations after six tumultuous years of conservative government. His Labor opponent, Bill Shorten, will resign his party leadership.

headline: Your Questions about the New Adversity Score on the SAT, Answered
abstract: What factors does it consider, and is it based on research? We explain.
lead_paragraph: The College Board, the company that administers the SAT exam, unveiled a new tool for admissions officers this week that measures the economic and social adversity that test takers have faced.

headline: De Blasio Once Ignored Trump. But in Iowa, It Was All Trump.
abstract: The mayor made his first trip to Iowa as a presidential candidate, showing off his new focus on criticizing Mr. Trump.

headline: Impeachment Is a Form of Hope
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Constitution (US)', 'Impeachment', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: The prosecution of President Andrew Johnson in 1868 was an attempt to restore faith in America’s original ideals.
lead_paragraph: When we talk about whether to impeach President Trump, we cite the near impeachment of Richard Nixon or the actual prosecution of Bill Clinton. Oddly, though, we don’t talk much about the first-ever presidential impeachment, which very nearly succeeded in removing Andrew Johnson from office.

headline: After Alabama Abortion Law, 3 Democrats Propose a New Strategy
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Roe v Wade (Supreme Court Decision)']
abstract: Senators Cory Booker, Kirsten Gillibrand and Elizabeth Warren are taking an aggressive approach in a debate whose terms have long been set by conservatives.
lead_paragraph: Responding to a series of highly restrictive abortion laws aimed at overturning Roe v. Wade, several Democratic presidential candidates have called on Congress to codify abortion rights, signaling a newly aggressive approach in a debate whose terms have long been set by conservatives.

headline: Jim Jordan Claims Vindication, but Inquiry Says Talk of Abuse at Ohio State Was Rampant
keywords: ['Wrestling', 'Coaches and Managers', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: An investigation into a team doctor’s sexual abuse found no hard evidence that coaches like Mr. Jordan knew, but it said dozens of other coaches acknowledged rumors of the doctor’s predatory behavior.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A major investigation into sexual abuse at Ohio State University found no hard evidence that coaches like Jim Jordan, now a prominent Republican in Congress, knew of a team doctor’s rampant sexual misconduct. But the 182-page report released on Friday said dozens of other coaches acknowledged that rumors of the doctor’s predatory behavior were rife.

headline: Tiger Woods Misses the Cut at the P.G.A. Championship by 1 Stroke
abstract: Woods had hoped to build on an exhilarating Masters win in April. Instead, he had two rounds of bogey-filled golf.
lead_paragraph: FARMINGDALE, N.Y. — The Tiger Woods of old entered every tournament expecting to win. An older, wiser Woods returned last year from his fourth back operation with tempered expectations.

headline: Former C.I.A. Officer Sentenced to 20 Years After Spying for China
abstract: The sentencing brings to a close one of several high-profile cases involving Chinese attempts to recruit former American intelligence officers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A former C.I.A. officer was sentenced on Friday to 20 years in prison by a federal judge in Northern Virginia for passing secrets to China in return for $25,000, bringing to a close one of several cases involving Chinese attempts to recruit former American intelligence officers.

headline: A Harlem Team Is Changing the Face of Lacrosse
abstract: Frederick Douglass Academy in Harlem is playing for its third straight New York City boys’ lacrosse title. The team is a sign of progress for a sport seen as elite, suburban and mostly white.
lead_paragraph: The boys’ varsity lacrosse team that is playing this weekend for its third consecutive New York City public schools championship practices on a concrete handball court in a city park with no lights, no room for spectators and broken fencing.

headline: German Parliament Deems B.D.S. Movement Anti-Semitic
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Jews and Judaism', 'ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The campaign to boycott Israeli artists and goods recalled “the most terrible chapter in German history” and revived memories of the motto “Don’t buy from Jews.”
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The German Parliament on Friday became the first in the European Union to pass a symbolic resolution that designates the Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions, or B.D.S., movement against Israel as anti-Semitic.

headline: Unita Blackwell, 86, Dies; Rights Crusader and Winner of Historic Election
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: A sharecropper’s daughter, she joined the voter-registration fight before becoming the first black woman elected a mayor in Mississippi.
lead_paragraph: Unita Blackwell, who was born in a sharecropper’s shack in Mississippi in the depths of the Depression, grew up having no idea what it meant to vote. She did not even know the word.

headline: Boeing 737 Max Simulators Are in High Demand. They Are Flawed.
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Pilots']
abstract: The flight simulators are unable to accurately replicate the difficult conditions created by a malfunctioning system on the jet, which played a role in two fatal crashes.
lead_paragraph: Since the two fatal crashes of the Boeing 737 Max, airlines around the world have moved to buy flight simulators to train their pilots.

headline: At P.G.A. Championship, Rory McIlroy Is Almost Finished Off by His Start
abstract: He was supposed to be the heir apparent to Tiger Woods. At Bethpage State Park, McIlroy was just happy to make the cut.
lead_paragraph: FARMINGDALE, N.Y. — When Rory McIlroy finished his second round at Bethpage State Park’s Black Course on Friday, he tried to reconcile the difference between the two double bogeys in his first three holes and the four birdies over his last six.

headline: U.S. Officials Say Iran Has Removed Missile Threat From Some Boats
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Missiles have been unloaded from at least two small boats in Iranian waters, a move that American officials said could help defuse a brewing confrontation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Iran has unloaded missiles from at least two small boats in its territorial waters in what two American officials said on Friday was a sign of easing tensions in the brewing confrontation between Washington and Tehran.

headline: Barr Again Casts Doubt on Russia Inquiry’s Origins, Aligning With Trump’s Attacks
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Mr. Barr said his review of the investigation has turned up “inadequate” answers. But some former officials expressed concern he was deliberately undercutting it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Attorney General William P. Barr described the early stages of the Russia investigation as “spying” on the Trump campaign, he prompted questions about whether he had used that word spontaneously — or whether he was deliberately fueling conspiracy theories.

headline: Money and Modern Strategy: How the Depleted Yankees Kept Winning
abstract: Despite 17 players spending time on the injured list this year, the Yankees have kept pace in the A.L. East with smart moves rather than splashy ones.
lead_paragraph: For most teams, 17 players making trips to the injured list — including a major-league-leading 13 currently — only a quarter of the way through the season would be crippling.

headline: Brooks Koepka Makes History on Day 2 of the P.G.A. Championship
abstract: Koepka set a record for the lowest 36-hole score at a major on Friday as he surged to a seven-shot lead.
lead_paragraph: FARMINGDALE, N.Y. — With powerful, audacious swipes at the golf ball and deft putting, Brooks Koepka did not flinch Friday as he continued a dauntless assault on the intimidating Bethpage State Park Black Course at the P.G.A. Championship.

headline: When Will Eric Garner Get Justice?
abstract: Mayor de Blasio owes Mr. Garner’s family — and the city — answers.
lead_paragraph: As Eric Garner lay dying, he was gasping for air and bleeding in his neck and eyes. The arm of a New York City police officer was pressed hard against his throat.

headline: SAT Adversity Index: A Drive Toward Diversity Without Discussing Race
keywords: ['SAT (College Admission Test)', 'Tests and Examinations', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Education (K-12)', 'AFFIRMATIVE ACTION']
abstract: The College Board, which administers the SAT, is joining a broadening movement toward using race-neutral alternatives to affirmative action.
lead_paragraph: The decision to give students who take the SAT test a numerical rating that reflects the challenges they have overcome in life is the most telling sign yet that universities across the country are searching for ways to diversify their classes without considering race or ethnicity.

headline: Dear Millennials: The Feeling Is Mutual
abstract: Joe Biden dares to take offense at those who specialize in being offended.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, a video of Joe Biden saying he had “no empathy” for “the younger generation” that “tells me how tough things are” resurfaced on social media. The video was over a year old, but it elicited predictable howls from members of the dissed demographic. “Nothing says ‘perfect candidate to lead the most powerful nation in the world’ like ‘I have no empathy,’” wrote someone with the Twitter handle @anarchopriapism.

headline: Citrus Farmers Facing Deadly Bacteria Turn to Antibiotics, Alarming Health Officials
abstract: In its decision to approve two drugs for orange and grapefruit trees, the E.P.A. largely ignored objections from the C.D.C. and the F.D.A., which fear that expanding their use in cash crops could fuel antibiotic resistance in humans.
lead_paragraph: ZOLFO SPRINGS, Fla. — A pernicious disease is eating away at Roy Petteway’s orange trees. The bacterial infection, transmitted by a tiny winged insect from China, has evaded all efforts to contain it, decimating Florida’s citrus industry and forcing scores of growers out of business.

headline: As the Blues Seek the Stanley Cup, a Hockey Hub Grows in St. Louis
abstract: The pipeline of American hockey, which snakes from Massachusetts west into Michigan and Minnesota, has meandered south, to Missouri.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — Scott Rupp flipped open the red spiral notebook he keeps as president of the St. Louis Amateur Hockey Hall of Fame and ran his index finger down the inside cover, along a column of surnames and birthdays that swells every year. Written in neat blue penmanship, they represent players who grew up in the area and have appeared in the N.H.L.

headline: Women in India, Tell Us How You Voted in This Election and Why
abstract: Help us understand the concerns that drove a wave of women  to the polls in the world’s biggest election.
lead_paragraph: A record number of women were expected to vote in India’s general election, and for the first time, they may account for half or more of the total votes cast — all at a moment when the country faces a slowing economy, societal divisions and environmental challenges, among other issues.

headline: Trump Administration Flying Migrants Out of Texas to Ease Overcrowding at Border
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Immigration Detention']
abstract: The Department of Homeland Security has begun flying recent border-crossers and asylum seekers to California in a program that may expand to coastal areas and the Canadian border.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hundreds of migrants are being flown from South Texas to holding cells in California by the Department of Homeland Security, in a move that officials said on Friday could be expanded by sending asylum seekers to processing centers throughout the United States, including the border with Canada.

headline: Corrections: May 18, 2019
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, May 18, 2019.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Reflections on the Graduation of My Daughter
abstract: It’s never too late to grow or to love.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It’s college graduation month, time of reunions and reflections, an ending and a commencement, and as good a moment as any to take stock. To watch a child go out into the world is to know that there is no hiding from the real measure of your life.

headline: For Tiger Woods, the Love Is as Big as Ever
abstract: He was never all that lovable a figure, and he is hardly an exemplar of fine behavior off the course, but fans love golf’s past and current king.
lead_paragraph: FARMINGDALE, N.Y. — The crowds following Tiger Woods on the Black Course at Bethpage State Park this week looked more like a marauding army than a gathering of golf fans on a pleasant day. They trampled everything in their path and went under and over ropes designed to prevent them from doing exactly that. One fan even broke a fence trying to get a better view of Woods over the swarming masses.

headline: Does Anyone Actually Want Joe Biden to Be President?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: What ‘electability’ seems to mean in 2020 — and what it meant in 2018.
lead_paragraph: The most important requirement for the Democratic Party’s presidential nominee? Electability. It matters more, we keep hearing, than nominating a candidate who has good policies. It matters more than nominating a candidate with a track record of passing progressive legislation. It certainly matters more than nominating a candidate who could be the first female president.

headline: Hard Core
abstract: Andy Kravis and Erik Agard take us on a wild ride.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE  — I’ll call this puzzle classic Andy Kravis and Erik Agard, although it feels funny to use the term “classic” to refer to two extremely young people, practically children. But no matter! They have flair, and when working together create puzzles with a distinctive, improvisatory feel. There are times when I think I can tell when one particular entry begets another, in a themeless puzzle, and it makes the solve cozy and fun. Maybe that flow is a little reminiscent of a game show, something both these constructors have in common, or maybe it’s something else to do with their personalities, but they always come up with appealing and gratifying grids.

headline: Corroded Well Lining Caused Aliso Canyon Gas Leak That Displaced Thousands, Report Says
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Natural Gas', 'Methane', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Drilling and Boring']
abstract: An inquiry found that SoCalGas had not meaningfully investigated more than 60 leaks before the one in October 2015 that became the largest leak of methane in United States history.
lead_paragraph: For more than 100 days in 2015 and 2016, gas leaked out of the Aliso Canyon Natural Gas Storage Facility near Los Angeles — the largest known leak of methane in United States history. More than 8,300 households were evacuated, and people exposed to the gas reported nosebleeds, dizziness and respiratory problems.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Venezuela Reels as Economy Falls
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, May 18, 2019.
lead_paragraph: “It’s really hard to think of a human tragedy of this scale outside civil war.”

headline: Horse Deaths at Santa Anita and Pimlico: Same Day, Same Track Owner
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Preakness Stakes']
abstract: A filly died after a race on Friday at Pimlico, the site of Saturday’s Preakness Stakes. The fatality at Santa Anita, the 24th at the track since Dec. 26, occurred after a gelding broke down during training.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Two horses died at racetracks owned by the Stronach Group on Friday, keeping the issue of animal safety in horse racing in the public eye on the eve of one of the biggest days in horse racing.

headline: Protests at the Whitney Over a Board Member Whose Company Sells Tear Gas
abstract: About 200 people squeezed into the lobby of the Whitney Museum of American Art in the ninth of a series of weekly gatherings that have become part of a prolonged public debate.
lead_paragraph: Visitors who arrived at the Whitney Museum of American Art on Friday night to view the works in this year’s politically tinged Biennial had to pass by a raucous demonstration that was not part of the official programming.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘S.N.L.’ and ‘Fleabag’
abstract: “Saturday Night Live” Season 44 comes to an end. And “Fleabag” is back on Amazon Prime Video.
lead_paragraph: “Saturday Night Live” Season 44 comes to an end. And “Fleabag” is back on Amazon Prime Video.

headline: On Politics: The Biggest Stories of the Week
abstract: It’s been a busy week in American politics. Here are some of the stories you might have missed.
lead_paragraph: From rising tensions with Iran to the still-growing Democratic presidential field, it’s been a busy week in American politics. Here are some of the biggest stories you might have missed (and some links if you’d like to read further).

headline: The Week in Arts: Renée Zellweger as a Temptress; Tilda Swinton and her Daughter as Co-Stars
keywords: ['Art', 'Classical Music', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Movies', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: “Mac Beth” actors wear school uniforms, Julia Michaels is at Bowery Ballroom, and Honor Swinton Byrne appears in “The Souvenir.”
lead_paragraph: Through July 29; sculpture-center.org

headline: To Many Chinese, America Was Like ‘Heaven.’ Now They’re Not So Sure.
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Customs (Tariff)']
abstract: As the trade war rages, ambivalence in China about the United States has posed an unusual challenge for the Communist Party.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Qi Haohan describes with pride the times he has leaped and pirouetted with American dancers across stages in China, and he counts as a major influence Daniil Simkin, a principal dancer with the American Ballet Theater.

headline: One of U.K.’s Most Prolific Extremist Cells Is Regrouping
abstract: The security services have expressed alarm at the prospect of the extremist group Al Muhajiroun re-energizing with ISIS fighters returning from Iraq and Syria.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Even as fellow European countries worry about hardened Islamic State fighters returning from Syria and Iraq, Britain has another problem: the re-emergence of a homegrown militant cell, Al Muhajiroun, one of Europe’s most prolific extremist networks, which was implicated in the London  bombings of 2005.

headline: The First Presidential Impeachment
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Impeachment', 'Constitution (US)', 'Reconstruction Era', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Brenda Wineapple’s “The Impeachers” is a revealing history of the trial of Andrew Johnson in 1868.
lead_paragraph: THE IMPEACHERS The Trial of Andrew Johnson and the Dream of a Just Nation By Brenda Wineapple

headline: Fact-Checking Joe Biden on the Campaign Trail
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Mandatory Sentencing', 'Violence Against Women Act (1994)']
abstract: Since announcing his candidacy, he has defended his decades-long record on criminal justice and climate change, rejected assertions he is a moderate and gone after President Trump. Here’s how his claims stack up.
lead_paragraph: In the three weeks since former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. announced his candidacy for the Democratic presidential nomination in 2020, he has been widely portrayed in polls and commentary as the front-runner.

headline: A Stolen Letter Written by Alexander Hamilton in 1780 Resurfaces
keywords: ['Archives and Records', 'Revolutionary War, American (1775-83)', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Auctions']
abstract: The letter, taken by a Massachusetts Archives employee more than 70 years ago, was discovered by a researcher at an auction house in Virginia. It is valued at least $25,000.
lead_paragraph: A letter written by Alexander Hamilton during the Revolutionary War has resurfaced more than seven decades after the document was stolen from the Massachusetts Archives, federal authorities said.

headline: An American Pilot, a Muslim Teenager and a Talking Dog All Caught in an Absurd War
abstract: “Red Birds,” a new novel by the Pakistani author Mohammed Hanif, satirizes America’s never-ending military conflicts in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: RED BIRDS By Mohammed Hanif

headline: Facial Recognition: Dawn of Dystopia, or Just the New Fingerprint?
keywords: ['Computer Vision', 'Face', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Police', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Privacy']
abstract: San Francisco banned it, but many police departments say the technology is used no differently from DNA databases or other crime-fighting tools.
lead_paragraph: Every couple of months, Officer Michael Zinn of the York Area Regional Police Department in Pennsylvania ran a photo of a man through the department’s facial recognition software. In a year and a half of searches, the result was always the same: No hits.

headline: Hotel Review: The Virgin Hotels San Francisco
abstract: A brand that loves to party opens a hotel with a huge rooftop bar in a city that knows a thing or two about night life.
lead_paragraph: Starting at $195

headline: In Cities Where It Once Reigned, Heroin Is Disappearing
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Heroin', 'Fentanyl', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Opioids and Opiates', 'your-feed-healthcare']
abstract: The rise of the more potent fentanyl in its place has put a generation of older users, who had managed their addiction, at far greater risk of overdose.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Heroin has ravaged this city since the early 1960s, fueling desperation and crime that remain endemic in many neighborhoods. But lately, despite heroin’s long, deep history here, users say it has become nearly impossible to find.

headline: ‘I Did My Best to Stop American Foreign Policy’: Bernie Sanders on the 1980s
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In an interview, one of the leading candidates for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination discusses his long-held opposition to war and his support for socialist leaders.
lead_paragraph: [Read more: Bernie Sanders drops out of 2020 democratic presidential race.]

headline: Hannibal Lecter’s Creator Cooks Up Something New (No Fava Beans or Chianti)
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Book Trade and Publishing']
abstract: The “Silence of the Lambs” author Thomas Harris, overshadowed by the cannibal he invented, has kept a low profile for over 40 years.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Thomas Harris, the creator of one of literature’s most terrifying monsters, arguably has one of the darkest imaginations of any writer working today. His infamous serial killer, Hannibal Lecter, devours his victims’ organs after delicately preparing them, and once ate a man alive, serving slices of his brain with truffles and caper berries.

headline: Pub Work Gives a Royal Carpet Maker an Unwelcome Image (and It’s Sticking)
keywords: ['Carpets and Rugs', 'Royal Families', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Social Media']
abstract: Axminster has Buckingham Palace’s seal of approval. But thanks to social media, its best-known client is a chain of cut-price bars.
lead_paragraph: AXMINSTER, England — The royal coat of arms is affixed to a sign on the front of the Axminster Carpets factory, near the train station in this town of 6,000 in southwest England. Beneath the seal are the words “By Appointment to Her Majesty the Queen/Carpet Manufacturer.”

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
abstract: Wesley Morris binges “Game of Thrones.” Olivia Wilde, the director. I.M. Pei dies. Thomas Harris speaks. The Gen X mess. And more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the weekend. I woke up this week and found out my generation (X) is “a mess.” I’m not sure I agree, but you should decide for yourself. There was much news to digest this week, on Iran, abortion and tariffs. Here are some other stories you might have missed.

headline: A Merging of ‘Two Different Worlds’
abstract: The bride and groom had different cultural and religious backgrounds, but managed to “fit in pretty seamlessly” in each others’ families.
lead_paragraph: Hedieh Fakhriyazdi and Michael Anthony Pasnello II were married May 17 at the Foundry, an events space in Long Island City, Queens. The Rev. Brian Van Fossen, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated. Earlier in the day, the couple took part in a Baha’i Faith marriage ceremony led by Trisha Irons, a longtime friend of the bride’s family.

headline: As India’s Election Ends, Warring Parties Burn a Village
abstract: India has seen less violence than usual during this election season, which ends Sunday. But political and sectarian anger left at least one village scarred.
lead_paragraph: BOGAKHALI, India — Riya Mondal could not stop crying. Standing in front of the burned-out shell of her family’s home and adjacent appliance repair shop, she pointed to the blackened cage that once held her two beloved parrots.

headline: Austrian Leader Calls for Snap Election After Far-Right Vice Chancellor Resigns
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Elections', 'Government Contracts and Procurement', 'Newspapers', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: A 2017 video that was secretly filmed showed Vice Chancellor Heinz-Christian Strache promising government contracts to a woman claiming to be the niece of a Russian oligarch.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Austria’s leadership was thrown into turmoil on Saturday after a video emerged that raised questions about whether Russia had direct influence inside a government at the heart of Europe.

headline: Colombia Army’s New Kill Orders Send Chills Down Ranks
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Politics and Government', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Senior officers told The Times that soldiers are under intense pressure to defeat rebel groups and that a pattern of suspicious killings and cover-ups has begun to emerge this year.
lead_paragraph: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — The head of Colombia’s army, frustrated by the nation’s faltering efforts to secure peace, has ordered his troops to double the number of criminals and militants they kill, capture or force to surrender in battle — and possibly accept higher civilian casualties in the process, according to written orders and interviews with senior officers.

headline: Maternity Leave for Sponsored Runners
keywords: ['Athletics and Sports', 'Running', 'Women and Girls', 'Family Leaves', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Marathon Running']
abstract: A video about female runners losing their pay and health insurance if they are pregnant sends ripples through the running world.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Running newsletter! Every Saturday morning, we email runners with news, advice and some motivation to help you get up and running. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: A Label in Need: The Week in Classical Music
abstract: Plácido Domingo in zarzuela, an unplanned deficit at Tzadik and a young artists' gala were among the highlights.
lead_paragraph: Readers and listeners: The “Ring” is done. After two months and three cycles, the Metropolitan Opera’s Wagner immersion — and its season — has come to an end. I’ll refer you to Michael Cooper’s Twitter thread for the 15-odd stories and reviews we produced about this massive undertaking:

headline: 2019 Grads: Show Us Your Decorated Graduation Caps
abstract: And tell us the meaning behind them.
lead_paragraph: It’s graduation season, and for many of us, our Instagram feeds are full of decorated mortarboards. We’re intrigued by these works of art.

headline: What Does It Really Mean to Be 6 Weeks Pregnant?
keywords: ['Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'ABORTION', 'Law and Legislation', 'Women and Girls', 'Tests (Medical)', 'Birth Control and Family Planning']
abstract: So-called ‘heartbeat’ legislation restricting abortion as early as six weeks into pregnancy has started a conversation about when most women actually learn that they’re pregnant.
lead_paragraph: Now that several states have passed bills that effectively ban abortion after a fetal heartbeat can be detected, the new laws are raising a lot of questions about early pregnancy and miscarriage treatments.

headline: Guatemala’s Anti-Corruption Fight Inspired Latin America. It May Be Shut Down.
abstract: A panel of United Nations-backed investigators charged around 700 people. Other countries wanted their own anti-graft groups, but a coming election may spell its end.
lead_paragraph: GUATEMALA CITY — Jailed in the squalid barracks of a military base, members of Guatemala’s once untouchable elite plot their return to power.

headline: Eli Manning, Naomi Campbell and Paula Abdul on the Philanthropy Circuit
abstract: Fund-raisers were held for Robin Hood, Fierce and the Ellis Island Honors Society.
lead_paragraph: Fund-raisers were held for Robin Hood, Fierce and the Ellis Island Honors Society.

headline: Burkina Faso Racked by Escalating Violence
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: A once-stable country is plagued by extremists pouring over its northern border, restive farmers and herdsmen battling for land, and militias bent on tit-for-tat vengeance.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — A mission to rescue kidnapped tourists that went fatally awry. A church burned to the ground, the priest shot at Sunday Mass. A day later, another attack; four more Christians dead.

headline: Think You Know Who Will Win ‘Game of Thrones’? Fans Are Betting They Do
abstract: There has been a flurry of offshore and European wagering on the finale of the hit HBO show, but betting on a scripted series has its drawbacks.
lead_paragraph: The “Game of Thrones” character who will rule Westeros at the end of the series finale on Sunday didn’t fend off the army of the dead with a sword in Winterfell. Nor did they lead the charge through the gates of King’s Landing during the scorching butchery of the last episode.

headline: Australia Election Results: Prime Minister Scott Morrison Seizes a Stunning Win
abstract: By granting Mr. Morrison his first full term, Australians signaled their reluctance to bet on a new leader at a time when the economy has not suffered a recession in nearly 28 years.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Scott Morrison, Australia’s conservative prime minister, scored a surprise victory in federal elections on Saturday, propelled by a populist wave — the “quiet Australians,” he termed it — resembling the force that has upended politics in the United States, Britain and beyond.

headline: Our 10 Most Popular Recipes Right Now
abstract: Spicy turkey stir-fry, cheesy cauliflower toasts and more recipes.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, make Chez Ma Tante’s pancakes (above), Melissa Clark’s spicy turkey stir-fry (above) or any of the top dishes of the week. Click the “10 Most Popular Recipes” collection below for more recipes.

headline: In Their Words: Remembering I.M. Pei
abstract: The Modernist master left his mark on generations, from Renzo Piano and Norman Foster to David Adjaye and Billie Tsien.
lead_paragraph: I.M. Pei, who died May 16 at age 102, was endlessly charming, with a wide smile and impeccable manners. Competitors were sometimes thrown off by the unflappable geniality, since he was a shrewd competitor, adept at luring clients and pleasing them. He was also passionate about the power of architecture.

headline: British Reality Television Is a Theater of Cruelty
keywords: ['Reality Television', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Death and Dying']
abstract: It was obvious that “The Jeremy Kyle Show” was wrong. But someone had to die for it to be stopped.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Over the last 14 years, roughly 20,000 Britons have been invited onto “The Jeremy Kyle Show” to have their lives torn apart on national television.

headline: Will a Documentary Take Down the Polish Government?
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Priests', 'Politics and Government', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: A film exposing sex abuse by Catholic priests also exposes the corrupting ties between the church and the ruling political party.
lead_paragraph: Following sexual-abuse scandals in the United States, Britain, Ireland and Australia, it seems that the Roman Catholic Church may be on the verge of a similar catastrophe in Poland. But whereas the blowback from previous scandals has been largely confined to the church itself, this latest crisis could take down the country’s right-wing government as well — and undermine the tight grip the church holds over Polish society.

headline: South Africa’s Racist Founding Father Was Also a Human Rights Pioneer
keywords: ['Apartheid (Policy)', 'Treaty of Versailles (1919)', 'World War I (1914-18)', 'Politics and Government', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: How did Jan Smuts reconcile his belief in freedom abroad with his efforts to suppress it at home?
lead_paragraph: The ranks of diplomats gathered in Paris during the spring of 1919 included a most unusual member of the British imperial delegation: a youthful South African politician and general named Jan Christiaan Smuts. One of his country’s founding figures and a leading force behind the formation of the British Commonwealth, the League of Nations and the United Nations, Smuts helped shape the emergence of the post-World War II liberal order — even though, all the while, he helped craft segregationist white rule in South Africa. How did he reconcile his promotion of human rights abroad and suppression of them at home? And how should we weigh this complicated, flawed but important figure, a century later?

headline: In the East, It Has Been All Bucks So Far (but Not All Giannis)
abstract: Milwaukee is just two wins against the Raptors from its first N.B.A. finals appearance since 1974 behind the play of Giannis Antetokounmpo and a solid supporting cast.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — “Are they just a regular-season team?” the narrative setters and talking heads asked as the Bucks rolled to the N.B.A.’s best record. Then they swept a hapless Detroit Pistons team in the first round of the playoffs.

headline: Variety: Marching Bands
abstract: Joel Fagliano twirls his baton — voilà!
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE  — “Marching Bands” are always so imposing at first glance, but when broken down, I think they’re one of our more accessible offerings on Sunday. You’re given two sets of clues, as in a regular crossword, and your entries similarly overlap.

headline: Highlights From the Video That Brought Down Austria’s Vice Chancellor
abstract: A woman who said she was the niece of a Russian oligarch. A villa on Ibiza. A secret videotape. Lots of alcohol.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A secretly filmed video that led Heinz-Christian Strache, Austria’s far-right vice chancellor, to step down on Saturday is filled with eyebrow-raising moments, according to excerpts published by the German newsmagazine Der Spiegel and the newspaper Süddeutsche Zeitung.

headline: ‘This Is a Wave’: Inside the Network of Anti-Abortion Activists Winning Across the Country
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Law and Legislation', 'State Legislatures', 'Roe v Wade (Supreme Court Decision)', 'States (US)']
abstract: The raw cultural momentum of the anti-abortion movement has taken over, and it shows no signs of slowing.
lead_paragraph: State after state is passing sweeping abortion restrictions this year, from Alabama’s near total abortion ban, to Ohio’s ban after a fetal heartbeat is detected, to Utah’s ban after a pregnancy reaches 18 weeks. Already, eight states have passed laws that could challenge federal protections for abortion, with more on the way, prompting jubilation on the right and fear on the left.

headline: How Moms and Dads Divide the Work
abstract: Readers offer their views of this hot-button issue, including how they have tried to find the right formula to make a partnership work.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: F.A.A. Urges Commercial Flights to ‘Exercise Caution’ Over Persian Gulf
abstract: Amid escalating tensions between the United States and Iran, the agency alerted airliners to a growing risk of “misidentification” when flying in the region.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Aviation Administration has warned all American air carriers to “exercise caution” when flying over the Persian Gulf and the Gulf of Oman, saying that civilian aircraft are at “increasing” risk because of the escalating political tensions in the region.

headline: Running Scared: Network TV in the Streaming Age
abstract: Viewers are fleeing for Netflix. The ones who stay are older than the group prized by advertisers. Here’s a look back at the troubled 2018-19 season.
lead_paragraph: As the curtain comes down on the 2018-19 television season, the major broadcast networks found themselves sinking deeper into trouble.

headline: The Week in Business: A Facial Recognition Ban, and Trade War Blues
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)', 'Upfronts (Television)', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Delivery Services']
abstract: Also: Worries about another war, and the continuing crisis at Boeing.
lead_paragraph: Hello! I’m filling in this week for Charlotte, who’s off tallying her losses from the recent stock market dive. Here’s what you need to know in business news.

headline: Former Argentine President Kirchner Seeks Return to Power, as Vice President
abstract: Days before she was set to go on trial for corruption, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner announced an unexpected political strategy.
lead_paragraph: Days before she is set to go on trial on corruption charges, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner announced on Saturday that she intends to return to the presidential palace this year, this time as vice president running alongside Alberto Fernández, a former ally with whom she has had an uneasy relationship.

headline: Is War Coming With Iran? We’re Already in One
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: And Yemenis are paying the price.
lead_paragraph: Is America headed for a war involving Iran?

headline: San Francisco Banned Facial Recognition. New York Isn’t Even Close.
keywords: ['Computer Vision', 'Face', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Privacy', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The city still hasn’t passed a bill mandating disclosure of the use of new surveillance technologies.
lead_paragraph: Very little is known about the New York Police Department’s use of facial recognition technology. What kind of facial recognition is in place? Which databases are being used? How many people have been scanned, and why? How long is their data retained? Are the police sharing facial recognition data with federal agencies like Immigration and Customs Enforcement, or even private corporations?

headline: Luddites Shall Inherit the Earth
abstract: Someone will have to call our landlines to tell us it’s ours now.
lead_paragraph: Luddites, welcome.

headline: How High School Ruined Leisure
abstract: Will kids still do what they like when it won’t help them get into college?
lead_paragraph: Summer is coming.

headline: I Was Racially Taunted on Television. Wasn’t I?
keywords: ['Baseball', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Discrimination', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Whites', 'Fringe Groups and Movements']
abstract: Bigotry thrives in vagueness. It can be cowardly with double meanings.
lead_paragraph: Ambiguity has always been a friend to racism.

headline: ‘I Had Completely Lost the Knack for Staying Alive’
keywords: ['Spring (Season)', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: Warmer weather brings daffodils, rhubarb at the farmer’s market — and, for some, despair.
lead_paragraph: It’s a popular and perhaps dangerous belief, reinforced by that inescapable Christmas classic “It’s a Wonderful Life,” that winter is the peak season for suicide. Yet experts have known since the late 1800s that it’s not true: More people take their own lives in the spring months than in other times of the year. No definitive explanations have emerged for why this is so.

headline: Don’t Fight Iran
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: How a war in the Middle East would wreck Trump’s grand strategy.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes it’s important to write a column about something you’re pretty sure isn’t going to happen. In this case, that thing is war with Iran, which Donald Trump clearly doesn’t want, and which he will therefore probably avoid. But since the president’s current foreign policy is making war more likely, it’s still worth saying clearly that it would be a terrible idea for the United States to enter into a serious armed conflict with the Islamic Republic of Iran.

headline: The Suburbs Are Coming to a City Near You
keywords: ['Suburbs', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Urban Areas', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Millennial Generation']
abstract: Is a city still a city if urban living is a luxury good?
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The roof deck of this new apartment complex is over half of an acre, and currently a concrete construction zone. But soon it will have a grass lawn, benches, hammocks and 20 planter boxes that residents can use to grow vegetables.

headline: Religious Men Can Be Devoted Dads, Too
keywords: ['Marriages', 'Religion and Belief', "Women's Rights", 'Women and Girls', 'Men and Boys', 'Parenting', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Faith, like feminism, sets high expectations for husbands.
lead_paragraph: “Blue” marriages are better — or at least that is the conventional wisdom. Couples who live according to egalitarian values, sharing domestic responsibilities like housework and cooking, have long been seen as superior by most academics, journalists and public intellectuals engaged in the national conversation about the American family.

headline: Black Women in Chicago, Getting Things Done
abstract: How the rest of the country can follow them.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Chicago will make history when Lori Lightfoot becomes the city’s first black female mayor. This victory sits alongside other firsts: her recent runoff against Toni Preckwinkle, a black woman and the president of the Cook County Board of Commissioners, and the 2016 election of Kim Foxx, a black woman, as the city’s top prosecutor.

headline: Lyon Routs Barcelona to Win Fourth Straight Women’s Champions League Title
abstract: Lyon, the gold standard in women’s club soccer, scored four times in the first 30 minutes and earned its sixth European crown since 2011.
lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — It was never in doubt.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Is Going Out Fighting. So Will Its Audience.
abstract: The arguments over HBO’s dark fantasy made it the signature show of an era when no one agrees on anything.
lead_paragraph: Who will win the Iron Throne? Who should win the Iron Throne? Should there even be an Iron Throne?

headline: Biden Delivers Call for National Unity at Philadelphia Rally
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: Mr. Biden trained his eye squarely on the general election as he cast the contest against President Trump as a struggle for the soul of the country.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Joseph R. Biden Jr., sometimes known to Democrats in this city as Pennsylvania’s “third senator,” returned to the state of his birth on Saturday to deliver a forceful call for national unity, looking past the Democratic presidential primary to directly appeal to the voters who helped power President Trump’s victory in Pennsylvania and across the country in 2016.

headline: Steve Bannon Is a Fan of Italy’s Donald Trump
abstract: He’s crisscrossing Europe because he believes it’s a bellwether for the United States. The scary thing is he could be right.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — Italy is a political laboratory. During the Cold War, the question was whether the United States could keep the Communists from power. Then Italy produced Silvio Berlusconi and scandal-ridden showman politics long before the United States elected Donald Trump. Now, on the eve of European Parliament elections likely to result in a rightist lurch, it has an anti-immigrant, populist government whose strongman, Matteo Salvini, known to his followers as “the Captain,” is the Continent’s most seductive exponent of the new illiberalism.

headline: Trump May Be Preparing Pardons for Servicemen Accused of War Crimes
keywords: ['Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Memorial Day', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Military officials received expedited requests for paperwork needed to pardon several military members on or around Memorial Day.
lead_paragraph: President Trump has indicated that he is considering pardons for several American military members accused or convicted of war crimes, including high-profile cases of murder, attempted murder and desecration of a corpse, according to two United States officials.

headline: Will Trump Be the Sage One?
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Plot Twist: In Season 2 of Trumpworld, Trump tries to restrain his crazy advisers, rather than vice versa.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Only one person can save us from the dangerous belligerent in the White House.

headline: Conservative Group Wants to Bring ‘Brass Knuckles’ Approach to Judicial Fray
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Courts (US)', 'Appeals Courts (US)']
abstract: The group will be led by a former Senate and White House aide who was a central figure in the confirmations of Justices Neil M. Gorsuch and Brett M. Kavanaugh.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the latest escalation of partisanship surrounding federal judicial nominations, an advocacy group is being created on the right to maintain momentum behind the Republican judicial juggernaut and prepare for the inevitable next Supreme Court fight.

headline: Trump Warns That Rising Border Crossings May Require an Extra $1.4 Billion
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Immigration Detention', 'Illegal Immigration']
abstract: In a letter to Congress, the administration said the flow of unaccompanied children at the border has exceeded projections of just weeks ago and may require more money for housing and care.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration has warned Congress that the flow of unaccompanied migrant children at the southern border has increased even further than it anticipated just a few weeks ago and may require an additional $1.4 billion to provide housing and care.

headline: Hook-Ups
abstract: Just try to resist the allure of Natan Last’s puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — I hope nobody floundered today, but if you’re fighting on the line right now we’re here to help. I’m happy to admit that I got schooled by Natan Last’s terrific construction, but before I completely sunk to the depths of despair, that all-important eureka moment bubbled me right back to the surface for a satisfying breath of fresh air. Our subjects today might feel quite differently about the same experience, however!

headline: Bernie Sanders’s Education Plan Laments Rise of Charter Schools
abstract: In a 10-point declaration of his education policy priorities, the Vermont senator framed efforts to curtail charter schools as a means to “desegregate” public education.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders took aim at charter schools on Saturday, calling for a moratorium on federal funding for the schools in a declaration of his education policy priorities ahead of the 2020 election.

headline: 2019 Preakness: War of Will Wins in Dramatic Rebound From Kentucky Derby Loss
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'Preakness Stakes', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare']
abstract: War of Will, with Tyler Gaffalione riding once again, was not impeded this time, though another jockey’s tumble at the start provided a scare.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — The deep breaths came fast and furious in the opening moments of the 144th running of the Preakness Stakes, and for good reason: John Velazquez, a Hall of Fame jockey, was airborne one moment and in the dirt the next after his colt, Bodexpress, broke out of the starting gate like a rodeo horse rather than a thoroughbred.

headline: Breaking With Party, G.O.P. Lawmaker Says Trump’s Conduct Reaches ‘Threshold of Impeachment’
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)']
abstract: Representative Justin Amash, known as a contrarian, accused the president of engaging in “impeachable conduct.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Update on July 4: Justin Amash announced he was leaving the Republican Party, saying that “modern politics is trapped in a partisan death spiral.”

headline: How My Hometown Became the Epicenter of India’s Religious Politics
abstract: Hindu nationalists rose to electoral significance from the debris of the mosque they demolished in 1992.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Ayodhya is a small, placid temple town in northern India, considered holy by Buddhists, Jains and Muslims, and believed by most Hindus to be the birthplace of Ram, one of Hinduism’s most revered deities and the protagonist of the epic poem the Ramayana. My family comes from a nearby village. Though my parents lived in Kolkata, we spent our summer and winter vacations in Ayodhya.

headline: Why You Should Try to Be a Little More Scarce
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: Conventional wisdom tells us we should eagerly embrace every opportunity that comes our way, but playing a little hard to get has its advantages.

Emails, tweets, Slack messages — you name it — being affable and amenable is kind of my thing.

headline: ‘Make No Apologies for Yourself’
abstract: Are we writing for other disabled people, for the nondisabled, or for everyone? The work of these poets speaks for itself.
lead_paragraph: The seven poems you will find here below, as well as seven others that will follow in a second post, were curated by us over the past several months, and represent only a small segment of poets with disabilities writing vital, engaged and powerful work today. To arrive here, we asked many disabled poets to offer their work, and this process raised issues that permeate debates in the disability community. We learned that some poets prefer not to claim disability as an identity, publicly or at all, and because this is a “disability” series, those poets did not wish to offer their work. We were also faced with questions raised in the recent and provocative debate between “disability poetics” and “crip poetics”: Who is the audience? Are we writing for other disabled people? For the nondisabled, or for everyone? How do we write for both while emphasizing the disabled poet’s aesthetic?

headline: What’s on TV Monday: ‘Wrestle’ and ‘Carpool Karaoke Primetime Special’
abstract: A documentary about a struggling high school wrestling team airs on PBS. And Celine Dion joins James Corden for karaoke in a new special.
lead_paragraph: INDEPENDENT LENS: WRESTLE (2019) 10 p.m. on PBS (check local listings). This moving portrait follows four members of a wrestling team at a high school in Huntsville, Ala., as they train for the state championship and battle personal woes along the way. One student worries about having to graduate and provide for his pregnant girlfriend; another ignores the four medications his doctors prescribed for behavioral issues and turns to marijuana instead. Keeping them on track is a tough-love coach, Chris Scribner, who hopes the students won’t be denied college scholarships because of race or class. Jeannette Catsoulis named the documentary a Critic’s Pick in her review in The New York Times. “‘Wrestle’ isn’t slick or impartial, and doesn’t claim to be,” she wrote. “Yet the movie has a raw honesty that disdains forced uplift.”

This enchanting realm even had a suitably enchanting name: Bosnia and Herzegovina, as melodious as Narnia, Utopia or Shangri-La, worlds that exist in the imagination, not on maps.

headline: Shame and Salvation in the American South
abstract: I’m tempted to say there’s never been a worse time to be a sentient human being below the Mason-Dixon line, but I know that’s not true.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — The news emanating from the American South this year has been one long litany of assaults against human decency. In Alabama, a physician who performs an abortion in the case of rape may soon spend more time in prison than the rapist himself. In Mississippi, a family is suing the county and its sheriff for beating a black man to death in jail. Tennessee just executed a deeply repentant Christian convert who had lived an exemplary life in prison. Proponents of a “culture of life” don’t seem to recognize the incoherence of their position.

headline: Trump’s Position on the Mueller Report is Legally Ridiculous — and Dangerous
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Law and Legislation', 'Constitution (US)', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: Congress needs the full report to do its job.
lead_paragraph: You may have a hard time believing a key argument the Trump administration is using to rebuff efforts by Congress to obtain information legislators need to do their job. The administration has claimed — for example, in a letter from the White House counsel to the House Judiciary Committee in response to congressional subpoenas of the full Mueller report — that Congress must demonstrate to the administration’s satisfaction that the information would serve a “legitimate legislative purpose.” In effect, Congress must show that its interests fall within the power under Article I of the Constitution to pass new legislation.

headline: Your Car Knows When You Gain Weight
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Privacy']
abstract: Vehicles collect a lot of unusual data. But who owns it?
lead_paragraph: Cars produced today are essentially smartphones with wheels. For drivers, this has meant many new features: automatic braking, turn-by-turn directions, infotainment. But for all the things we’re getting out of our connected vehicles, carmakers are getting much, much more: They’re constantly collecting data from our vehicles.

headline: Breaking My Own Silence
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Education (K-12)', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Power is the confidence to speak for yourself.
lead_paragraph: It makes sense that I’m a writer, which allows me to draft, hesitate, then rewrite many times before I say anything that I can live with for good.

headline: You Can’t Trust the Far Right
abstract: The latest scandal in Austria shows that extremists can’t be tempered.
lead_paragraph: With just a few days to go before the European parliamentary elections, Austria’s government is in a tailspin. The implications for the rest of the Continent are profound.

headline: DealBook Briefing: Tech’s Cold War Just Started

headline: Hours After French Patient Is Taken Off Life Support, a Court Orders It Be Restored
abstract: Vincent Lambert was left in a vegetative state after a 2008 car accident. His family is split over removing life support, and his case has attracted intense attention from the media and politicians.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Just hours after doctors stopped artificially feeding and hydrating a 42-year-old Frenchman who has spent more than a decade in a vegetative state, a French court ruled late on Monday night that he must be put back on life support.

headline: The Choice in India: ‘Our Trump’ or a Messier Democracy
abstract: The results of India’s parliamentary election will reveal not just a decision on Narendra Modi, but a deeper decision on what kind of government Indians want.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — In Hungary, Viktor Orban demonized immigrants and secured an expansion of his power. In Turkey, Recep Tayyip Erdogan purged his enemies and won a new term. In Australia, Scott Morrison shrugged off calls for tougher carbon-emissions rules and was unexpectedly kept on as leader.

headline: U.S. Tech Suppliers, Including Google, Restrict Dealings With Huawei After Trump Order

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Fans Gripe About the Finale’s Pointy End (and a Water Bottle)
abstract: Many had questions: That’s the person to lead the realm? Did the women of Westeros get shortchanged? And was that a water bottle under Samwell’s chair?
lead_paragraph: “Game of Thrones” is finally complete. And for many fans, that’s the best that can be said about its final season.

headline: Rihanna Opens Up About Her New Clothing Line, the Future of Fashion and Her Next Album
abstract: For her next act, the pop star will become the first black woman in charge of a major luxury fashion house in Paris. Here, she gives T magazine an exclusive first look.
lead_paragraph: For her next act, the pop star will become the first black woman in charge of a major luxury fashion house in Paris. Here, she gives T magazine an exclusive first look.

headline: The Venice Biennale Plays It Safe, and Gets Lost in Fog
abstract: This edition includes some of the best global artists under 40. But it takes far too few risks.
lead_paragraph: VENICE — Every other spring I come to this waterlogged city, take the vaporetto to a garden in its eastern edge and walk into a large white building. This year, I had some trouble making it out. Here in the Giardini della Biennale, the principal site of the world’s most enduring exhibition of contemporary art, the Italian artist Lara Favaretto has enveloped the white central pavilion in a dense cloud of artificial fog. The words “La Biennale,” above the colonnade, fade into formlessness.

headline: New Mayor Lori Lightfoot Vows Death to ‘Kissing-the-Ring’ Chicago Rules
abstract: Ms. Lightfoot was sworn in as outgoing Mayor Rahm Emanuel and City Council members looked on. ‘Get ready, because reform is here,” she told them.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — With the members of the City Council, former Mayor Richard M. Daley and Mayor Rahm Emanuel looking on, Lori Lightfoot was sworn in as Chicago’s 56th mayor on Monday, lauding the city’s resilience and diversity while also vowing to kill old-style Chicago politics.

headline: Some San Francisco Leaders Back Raid on a Journalist. District Attorney Candidates Disagree.
abstract: Monday: Law enforcement defends facial recognition, “Rocketman” to hit theaters, Warriors on a roll and catching up with a formerly homeless artist
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Seven Things We Learned From Rihanna’s Exclusive Interview With T Magazine
abstract: As the pop mogul discusses and reveals her luxury fashion line for the first time, here are the takeaways.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, the French fashion conglomerate LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton announced, after months of speculation, that it would expand its partnership with the pop star Robyn Rihanna Fenty, 31, beyond the beauty industry by launching a fashion line called Fenty. It’s the first major fashion brand that LVMH has created from scratch in its history, and it represents another historic shift: Rihanna is now the first black woman at the helm of one of Paris’s luxury houses, long revered for maintaining the highest level (in terms of craftsmanship, aesthetics and, yes, cost — though more on that later) of clothing and accessory design.

headline: Raptors Need Double Overtime on an Off Night for the Bucks
abstract: Breaking down the last-second shots. (They mostly missed.)

But the Toronto Raptors managed to get a home victory in double overtime against the Milwaukee Bucks on Sunday and close their Eastern Conference championship series deficit to two games to one.

headline: What to Cook Right Now
abstract: David Tanis has a great new recipe for barbecue country-style pork ribs, and Melissa Clark has one for a roast chicken with a rhubarb glaze.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I was married on this day nearly 20 years ago, a rainy, windswept afternoon on the East End of Long Island, the wedding party standing beneath the American flag at the Legion Hall as if auditioning for a high-school production of “Our Town.” The D.J. cued up Desmond Dekker afterward, and there were raw clams and oysters for all. It was pretty great. I’d like to have the best clam chowder (above) with the kids for dinner tonight in celebration, and to play “Israelites” loud while I clean up afterward. Maybe you could join us in cooking or at least in spirit? Marriage is a good institution.

headline: Turmeric Takes a Star Turn in Cocktails
abstract: The spice widely praised as a curative superfood is showing up in a different kind of medication.
lead_paragraph: If cocktails look golden to you lately, it’s probably not because spring is here and the sun is out. Turmeric, the bright yellow-orange spice long used in South Asian and Middle Eastern cooking, is the latest ingredient to make the leap from the kitchen to the cocktail glass. Every upscale bar menu these days seems to have at least one drink containing the spice.

headline: Cannes Says It’s Making Strides for Equality. Some Women See Backward Steps.

headline: Why High-Class People Get Away With Incompetence
keywords: ['Hiring and Promotion', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Research', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: People who came from higher social classes were more likely to have an inflated sense of their skills, a new study found. This overconfidence was interpreted by strangers as competence.
lead_paragraph: In season four of NBC’s “Parks and Recreation,” Paul Rudd plays a wealthy businessman named Bobby Newport who runs for city council because he’s looking for something “easy” to do. He is asked during a debate how he’d fix the town. His answer: “I have no idea.” Still, the audience goes wild, much to the frustration of his rival, Leslie Knope.

headline: In Wendell Berry’s Essays, a Little Earnestness Goes a Long Way
abstract: In “What I Stand On,” a two-volume boxed set, the Kentucky-based farmer, conservationist, pacifist and moral critic offers his fiery dissent about nearly every aspect of modern life.
lead_paragraph: Every serious writer, I’ve heard it said, has one book whose title seems to sum up his or her oeuvre. For Wendell Berry, that book would almost certainly be “Another Turn of the Crank,” from 1995.

headline: Yes, African-Americans Drink Bourbon. You’d Never Know It From the Marketing.
abstract: Groups like the Black Bourbon Society have formed to share an appreciation of the whiskey, and distillers are finally starting to pay attention.
lead_paragraph: Who is the typical bourbon drinker? Judging by the marketing for most whiskeys, a safe guess would be a white man, of middle age, and Southern by birth or at least aspiration. It could be a blond woman in full Kentucky Derby pastels, holding a mint julep.

headline: He’s One of the Biggest Backers of Trump’s Push to Protect American Steel. And He’s Canadian.

lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Minutes after taking office on Monday, Ukraine’s new president, Volodymyr Zelensky, announced a snap parliamentary election that he hopes will consolidate his power and help him deliver on campaign promises to end endemic corruption and a prolonged separatist conflict.

lead_paragraph: In the earliest days of “Game of Thrones,” Sansa Stark was a bratty youngster with romantic dreams about princes and princesses and of someday wearing a crown of her own.

headline: Review: Girls Just Wanna Play ‘Mac Beth’
abstract: Erica Schmidt’s raucously exuberant adaptation finds common cause between rebellious teenagers and bloody-minded Shakespeare.
lead_paragraph: Candy jewelry. Some baby dolls. A stash of tampons. In the world of adolescent girls, items like these are ordinary features of the landscape. And so they are in Erica Schmidt’s bloody “Mac Beth,” an adaptation of the Shakespeare play that with its all-female cast becomes a raucous, sometimes impish, very dark-edged revel.

headline: Man Who Climbed Eiffel Tower Is Taken Into Custody

headline: The First Black Woman to Compete at Cannes Finds Her Voice in Africa
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Movies', 'Cannes International Film Festival', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The 36-year-old filmmaker Mati Diop traces the genesis of her first feature, “Atlantics,” to her re-exploration of her identity.
lead_paragraph: CANNES, France — The dead keep returning at this year’s Cannes Film Festival, eerie emissaries of deeply troubled times. Nowhere is that return more haunting than in “Atlantics,” a poetic ghost story about trauma, loss and the persistence of love. The biracial French director Mati Diop, 36, made the movie in Dakar, Senegal, where her uncle, Djibril Diop Mambéty, set his landmark postcolonial film, “Touki Bouki” (1973), about two young lovers who dream of leaving for Paris.

keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Executive Privilege, Doctrine of', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)', 'Subpoenas']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The fight over President Trump’s systematic stonewalling of Congress escalated on two fronts on Monday, as a federal judge upheld a subpoena for his financial records even as the White House instructed its former top lawyer to defy a subpoena to testify before lawmakers.

headline: Logic Adds a No. 1 Album to His 2019 Chart Toppers
abstract: “Confessions of a Dangerous Mind” topped the Billboard list after the rapper’s debut novel, “Supermarket,” had become a best seller.
lead_paragraph: Bobby Hall, the rapper known as Logic, already went to No. 1 once this year, with his debut novel, “Supermarket,” topping The New York Times’s paperback trade fiction list. Now he has a chart-topping album as well, as “Confessions of a Dangerous Mind” becomes Logic’s third No. 1 at Billboard.

headline: Review: One Afternoon, Two Spectacular Orchestras

headline: More Than Just Children’s Books
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Children and Childhood', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Krumulus, a small bookstore in Germany, has everything a kid could want: parties, readings, concerts, plays, puppet shows, workshops and book clubs.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — On a recent Saturday afternoon, a hush fell in the bright, airy “reading-aloud” room at Krumulus, a small children’s bookstore in Berlin, as Sven Wallrodt, one of the store’s employees, stood up to speak. Brandishing a newly published illustrated children’s book about the life of Johannes Gutenberg, the inventor of the printing press, he looked at the crowd of eager, mostly school-aged children and their parents. “Welcome to this book presentation,” he said. “If you fall asleep, snore quietly.”

headline: Tornadoes Pass Through Oklahoma and Texas, but the Region Is Largely Spared
abstract: Forecasters had said there was a rare “high risk” zone for potentially catastrophic tornadoes.

headline: Where Is President Duterte? A Weeklong Absence Fuels Speculation and Scrutiny
abstract: Rumors have swirled that President Rodrigo Duterte might be sick after he dropped out of the public eye for a week.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines is not known to shy away from the spotlight. His bombastic speeches and public appearances regularly make headlines in his home country and further afield.

headline: Are AirPods Worth the Costs?
abstract: Apple’s wireless earbuds have led to questions about personal tech as environmental scourge and punch line.
lead_paragraph: Apple released its first wireless earbuds, AirPods, in late 2016, and since then they’ve become more than a sleek solution to the conundrum of cords. They weren’t the first wireless earbuds, but they captured the popular imagination more than any competitor product.

headline: Guatemalan Boy Dies at Border Station While Awaiting Move to a Shelter

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A 16-year-old Guatemalan boy who officials said was sick with influenza was found dead at a Border Patrol station in South Texas on Monday morning, after a week of waiting in holding facilities to be sent to a shelter for migrant children.

headline: Is Italy’s Front-Runner a Marshmallow?
abstract: Matteo Salvini is far in the lead for this month’s European elections, but Italians are hard to rein in.
lead_paragraph: BERGAMO, Italy — On May 13, at a rally near here, the heartland of right-wing party the League, which is ahead in polls approaching this week’s European elections, its leader Matteo Salvini asked the police to remove a banner hanging from a window. It read: “You are not welcome.”

headline: Joko Wins Re-Election in Indonesia, Defeating Hard-Line Former General
abstract: The victory for President Joko Widodo, a moderate technocrat, was a repudiation of the sort of nationalist and faith politics that have brought strongmen to power around globe.
lead_paragraph: MEDAN, Indonesia — President Joko Widodo of Indonesia has succeeded in his bid for re-election, according to a full vote count released by the country’s election commission on Tuesday, in a repudiation of the nationalist and faith politics that have brought strongmen to power across the globe.

headline: Tuesday Could Be the Beginning of the End of Philadelphia’s Soda Tax

headline: Australia Isn’t Right-Wing. It’s Cautious.
abstract: The election upset shows that voters don’t want to rock the boat.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Ahead of Australia’s general election on Saturday, one party had campaigned on the idea that politics and the economy were rigged in favor of the elites. It attacked its opponent relentlessly for siding with the “top end of town.” It insisted that things needed to be shaken up to stop serving multinational corporations and vested interests. That party lost.

headline: The Morehouse Gift, in Context: An Average Black Graduate Has $7,400 More in Debt Than White Peers
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Student Loans', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: On Sunday, Robert F. Smith, a billionaire investor, shocked and delighted the 396 graduates of Morehouse College when he pledged to repay their student loans. headline: Ranking the Deaths in the Final ‘Game of Thrones’ Season
