headline: How Trump’s Trade War Is Being Fought Around the World
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Customs (Tariff)', 'North American Free Trade Agreement']
abstract: Mexico, China, Japan, Europe, Canada: The White House’s various conflicts add up to a broad assault on a postwar effort to build economic ties around the world.
lead_paragraph: President Trump on Thursday threatened to hit Mexico with new tariffs, escalating his immigration fight with America’s largest trading partner. And with that, he showed, once again, that he’s ready to employ trade as an all-purpose tool for his policy goals.

headline: Julian Assange Is Suffering Psychological Torture, U.N. Expert Says
keywords: ['Extradition', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Torture', 'Sex Crimes', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The United Nations special rapporteur on torture accused Britain, Sweden and the United States of persecuting the WikiLeaks founder and said he should not be extradited.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — A United Nations expert on torture said on Friday that an examination of the WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange in a British prison showed an alarming deterioration in his mental and physical state, and he sharply rebuked Britain, Sweden and the United States for “ganging up” on Mr. Assange.

headline: Flooded Danube Hampers Rescuers After Budapest Boat Accident

lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — Rescuers were fighting the currents of a flooded Danube river on Friday in search of survivors and of the wreck of the sightseeing boat that sank in the center of Budapest two days ago. But Hungarian officials offered little hope that any of the 21 people still listed as missing would be found alive.

headline: With ‘NOS4A2,’ Joe Hill Finally Sinks His Teeth Into TV
abstract: The AMC horror series is one of several adaptations the best-selling horror author (and son of Stephen King) has in the works, after multiple stalled attempts.

He was there to talk about a vile old man with rotten teeth who feasts on the souls of young children.

headline: The Hand of Native American Women, Visible at Last
abstract: The role of women art-makers in Native communities has gone widely ignored. Now a bold museum show, by and for these women, is shining a light on 1,000 years of their art.
lead_paragraph: In early June, an installation by a Native American artist will hang in the galleries of the Minneapolis Institute of Art, but it won’t look like Native art in any traditional sense. “Idiot Strings, The Things We Carry” (2017), by Sonya Kelliher-Combs, an Athabascan and Inupiat artist from Alaska, is a series of goat and sheep hide pouches attached to strings, forming floating pockets. They cast shadows on the ground, creating an ethereal effect.

It was 50 years ago next month that gay New Yorkers spontaneously rose up to protest police raids on the Stonewall Inn in Greenwich Village, catalyzing the gay liberation movement. Their actions were among the first instances of major resistance to the maltreatment and criminalization of gay people in America, and Pride Month is still one of their great legacies — four weeks of celebration of and in and for the L.B.G.T.Q. community here and around the globe.

When the Chicago Symphony Orchestra offered him a commission, he wrote a raw, seething symphony of rage and remembrance for friends who had died.

headline: A Tibetan Collection Fights a Battle That Small Museums Often Face
abstract: Limited staff, tight budgets and age have taken a toll on Staten Island’s Jacques Marchais Museum, but a major renovation is now being planned.
lead_paragraph: Jacques Marchais, an art dealer and collector, never traveled to Asia, but the artifacts she gathered from Tibet, as well as from Nepal, Mongolia and northern China, became the passion of her life. Her dream to display this collection to the public was realized in 1947 when, just a few months before her death, the Jacques Marchais Museum of Tibetan Art opened atop a hill on Staten Island, next door to her house.

headline: My New Favorite Herb
abstract: Pair loads of dill with your roast salmon or rice, or just top your pasta with burrata and call it a day.
lead_paragraph: Hi and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes, recipes for busy people who still want something good to eat. I have a tendency to go wild with herbs when I’m cooking, tossing them with abandon into salads and over vegetables, pasta and meat. My latest love is dill, fresh and feathery, thanks to the writer Naz Deravian and her Persian cookbook, “Bottom of the Pot.” I cooked a lot from it when I judged a round of the Piglet tournament of cookbooks on Food52 in March, and in that time my fridge became a leafy, branchy wonderland of herbs, which figure prominently in Persian cooking. (You can read our own Samin Nosrat on this very subject!)

headline: Review: In ‘Good Omens,’ Angel and Demon Try to Save the World
abstract: Based on Neil Gaiman and Terry Pratchett’s comic fantasy novel, the story finally makes it to the screen.
lead_paragraph: It’s taken a long time for “Good Omens: The Nice and Accurate Prophecies of Agnes Nutter, Witch,” Neil Gaiman and Terry Pratchett’s 1990 end-of-days fantasy novel, to reach the screen. Long enough for Gaiman, then a promising comics writer and Duran Duran biographer, to become an industry: The Amazon Prime Video mini-series “Good Omens,” which debuted Friday, is the third current television show based on his work, with Netflix’s “Lucifer” and Starz’s “American Gods.”

headline: Abortion Rights Groups See Northern Ireland’s Film Industry as Boycott Target
abstract: Abortion rights campaigners in Northern Ireland, a thriving film and TV production hub, are hoping to draw attention to their region’s stern laws.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — Abortion rights activists scored a major victory this week when several major media companies said they would rethink filming in the state of Georgia if a newly passed restrictive abortion law there goes into effect.

headline: What to Watch and Read if You’re Still Talking About the National Spelling Bee
abstract: This year’s spelling Olympics has ended (with eight winners!) but you can still feel the stress in this sampling of books and movies.
lead_paragraph: An eight-way tie! This year’s National Spelling Bee crowned more champions than ever before, with auslaut, erysipelas and bougainvillea among the words they spelled correctly on Thursday.

headline: Curbing Presidential Power, After Trump
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)']
abstract: A reader urges that more safeguards be added since “surely the framers of the Constitution could not have imagined a president such as Donald Trump.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Baltimore Symphony Musicians Are ‘Stunned’ After Concerts Are Canceled
abstract: They react by playing an unscheduled work, Elgar’s “Nimrod,” which is often used for deaths and tragedies.
lead_paragraph: For months, the management of the financially struggling Baltimore Symphony Orchestra has tried to negotiate cutting the number of weeks it pays its musicians to 40 weeks from 52. And its players have resisted, arguing that such a move would weaken the quality of the ensemble.

headline: Some Enchanted Ending: Debuts and Other Spectacular Feats at City Ballet
abstract: A look at company standouts as the spring season draws to a close with Balanchine’s “A Midsummer Night’s Dream.”
lead_paragraph: The magic works fast. From the moment the first child-fairy flitters across the stage, pausing front and center to ripple her arms like tiny, trembling wings, the regenerative power of George Balanchine’s “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” starts to take hold. Decent story ballets are hard to come by, but this New York City Ballet production, set to music by Felix Mendelssohn, has everything: humor, fantasy and spectacular dancing. Take anyone you know, of any age.

headline: 3 of This Year’s Spelling Bee Winners Are Friends From Dallas
abstract: The region, where the boys competed together and became friends, has emerged as something of a spelling juggernaut in recent years.
lead_paragraph: When students from the Dallas area took the stage for a regional spelling bee this spring, the competition was so intense that officials ran out of words, had to resort to a written test and, in the end, decided to send three top spellers to nationals.

headline: Lawsuit Could Cool a Fast-Growing Way of Giving to Charities
keywords: ['Philanthropy', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Personal Finances', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: The suit sheds light on concerns around donor-advised funds, which disburse money over time but offer an immediate tax deduction.
lead_paragraph: When Emily and Malcolm Fairbairn decided to make a $100 million gift in 2017 to organizations that combat Lyme disease, they chose Fidelity Charitable, the country’s largest charity by assets, to distribute the money.

headline: It’s Going Great for Richard Madden. That’s What Worries Him
abstract: The actor who plays Elton John’s manager in “Rocketman” decided he’d had enough of playing good guys bad things happen to.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to award shows, always listen to Julianne Moore.

headline: On Motherhood and ‘This One Thing That People Don’t Share’
keywords: ['Podcasts', 'Parenting', 'Women and Girls', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Social Media', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Babies and Infants', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)']
abstract: The voyeuristic consolations of the “Motherhood Sessions” podcast.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Friday afternoon, a stylish woman in her early 40s showed up at a Brooklyn podcasting studio to tape what was essentially a three-hour therapy session, which was to later be condensed and made available for the public to download.

headline: The N.F.L. Has Been Consumed by the Concussion Issue. Why Hasn’t the N.H.L.?
abstract: The N.H.L., with a lower profile and fewer dead players than the N.F.L., has fought hard against mounting evidence of a connection between head injury and the degenerative brain disease C.T.E.
lead_paragraph: The day after Mother’s Day was the eighth anniversary of the death of N.H.L. player Derek Boogaard. As usual, his mother, Joanne, spent a quiet day of reflection at home in Regina, Saskatchewan, and continued a tradition of writing a letter to her dead son to be published in the Regina Leader-Post.

headline: A Basketball Homecoming for Canada
abstract: The Times’s N.B.A. reporter, Scott Cacciola, reflects on the game’s growth in Canada, and how Toronto has become a hub for top basketball talent
lead_paragraph: About an hour before the start of the N.B.A. finals on Thursday night, Commissioner Adam Silver arrived for his pregame news conference and offered a history lesson.

headline: The Guests You’ve Met Before
keywords: ['Podcasts', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Ponzi and Pyramid Schemes']
abstract: Stepping into the same cab, but for a new story.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get this by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Choosing Whether or Not to Have a Baby
abstract: One reader, “an I.V.F. baby,” says every child deserves to feel “chosen”; another is grateful his unwed mother did not abort him.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Richard Prince and the New Meaning of High Art
abstract: Guests at Prince’s show in San Francisco got a peek at the artist’s latest paintings — and a sniff of his new cannabis venture.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The large, brightly colored canvases sparkled beside the white walls of the Gagosian Gallery downtown. Larry Gagosian, the art world’s megadealer, stood toward the back of the room in blue jeans and loafers while the star of the evening, Richard Prince, the artist perhaps best known for tweaking iconic images and pushing the boundaries of intellectual property, stood reticently at the gallery entrance in a blazer and black Dr. Martens boots.

headline: David Letterman 2.0, the Non-Ironic Version
abstract: On his Netflix show “My Next Guest Needs No Introduction,” he defers to fame, skips jokes and rarely challenges his guests. What happened?
lead_paragraph: On the first week of his original late-night talk show, David Letterman appeared on the streets of New York with a microphone in hand. “Much has been said about Alan Alda, the TV star, the film star, the writer, the humanitarian, the champion of minority causes,” he said in the grave voice of a “60 Minutes” correspondent. “But it’s surprising we don’t know much about Alan Alda, the lover of Chinese food.”

headline: Complete List: Who Supports an Impeachment Inquiry Against Trump?
abstract: More than 90 percent of House Democrats now support impeachment proceedings.
lead_paragraph: More than 90 percent of House Democrats now support impeachment proceedings.

headline: Sarah Silverman Has Written a Musical
abstract: Atlantic Theater Company will host the world premiere of “The Bedwetter,” based on her 2010 memoir, along with a new play by Stephen Adly Guirgis.
lead_paragraph: Most of us prefer to keep embarrassing adolescent stories to ourselves, but that’s not Sarah Silverman’s style. The comedian, actress and writer, who in 2010 shared her struggles with childhood incontinence in “The Bedwetter: Stories of Courage, Redemption, and Pee,” has turned the best-selling memoir into a musical that will debut as part of Atlantic Theater Company’s coming season.

headline: It’s More Than Nostalgia for Roger Federer at the French Open
abstract: The Big Three — Novak Djokovic, Rafael Nadal and Federer — are still in command and contention heading into the weekend at Roland Garros.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It has been another year of big round numbers for Roger Federer. He won his 100th career singles title in Dubai in February. On Friday, on a luminous afternoon when springtime Paris felt like the place they used to write songs about, he became the first person in tennis history to play a 400th Grand Slam singles match.

headline: Floods and Trump’s Trade War Create an Uncertain Year for Farmers
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Environment', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Corn', 'Floods', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Prices are rising and planting is far behind schedule as farmers face a complex new calculus about what to plant—or whether to plant at all.
lead_paragraph: Corn prices are rising as surging floodwaters and soaking rains — combined with President Trump’s trade war with China — are making it an exceptionally difficult year for farmers facing risky choices about what crops to plant, or whether to plant at all.

headline: Trade, Missouri, Spelling Bee: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: 12 Killed in Rampage at Municipal Center in Virginia
keywords: ['Virginia Beach, Va, Shooting (2019)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'internal-national collaboration']
abstract: Chief James A. Cervera of the Virginia Beach Police Department said at an evening news conference that the scene could “best be described as a war zone.”
lead_paragraph: VIRGINIA BEACH, Va. — A municipal building in Virginia Beach, Va., was turned into a scene of carnage on Friday afternoon after a longtime public utilities employee began firing indiscriminately at his co-workers with a handgun, the authorities said, killing a dozen people and injuring several others before dying after an extended shootout with the police.

headline: Secretive Bilderberg Meeting Draws Pompeo and Kushner
abstract: Top Trump administration officials are attending the annual Bilderberg Meeting, where political and business leaders swear never to publicly reveal what is discussed.
lead_paragraph: BERN, Switzerland — Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is on a weeklong trip to Europe where he is raising sensitive issues with national leaders — from Iranian missiles to Chinese technology to the economic collapse of Venezuela — but the most colorful conversations could take place this weekend out of public earshot in a secretive conclave at a Swiss lakeside resort.

headline: ‘Become My Mom Again’: What It’s Like to Grow Up Amid the Opioid Crisis
keywords: ['Opioids and Opiates', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Education (K-12)', 'Addiction (Psychology)', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Heroin', 'OxyContin (Drug)', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Call them Generation O, the children growing up in families trapped in a relentless grip of addiction, rehab and prison.
lead_paragraph: PORTSMOUTH, Ohio — Layla Kegg’s mother, back home after three weeks who knows where, says she’s done with heroin, ready for rehab and wants to be part of her daughter’s life. But Layla has heard all of this before and doesn’t believe a single word.

headline: Trump to Kick Off His Re-election Campaign on June 18 in Orlando
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: The announcement will come a little over four years after he declared his presidential bid at Trump Tower in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On June 15, 2015, Donald J. Trump descended an escalator inside his signature Manhattan property, Trump Tower, greeted the cheering supporters paid to attend, and announced an unlikely presidential candidacy.

headline: Marc Okkonen, Baseball Maven of a Sartorial Bent, Dies at 85
abstract: His painstaking research on 20th-century major league uniforms, and his artist’s hand, led to the definitive book on the subject.
lead_paragraph: Marc Okkonen was watching the movie “The Natural” in 1984 when his attention shifted from its story of the mysterious slugger Roy Hobbs, played by Robert Redford, to the uniforms worn by Hobbs’s opponents onscreen.

headline: Do You Use Chest Binders? Tell Us About Your Experience
abstract: We would like to hear from people who have used binding to flatten their chests.
lead_paragraph: A recent Times article on chest binding has incited a discussion among readers about the practice, which some transgender and gender-nonconforming people use to affirm their gender identity, and our coverage of it.

headline: The Lessons of Paris and the Violence of Hope
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The French-American bond is bigger and stronger than Trump’s hatefulness.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — To be a Francophile is a life sentence. It’s not exactly a badge of honor, not a burden either, but a slightly illicit gift of ever-renewed pleasures.

headline: As China Takes Aim, Silicon Valley Braces for Pain
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Computers and the Internet', 'United States International Relations', 'Software', 'Computer Chips', 'Smartphones']
abstract: The tech cold war is heating up. U.S. companies that depend on the giant China market are preparing themselves for the fallout.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Silicon Valley looks west to China, it sees many things. More than a billion hungry consumers. A cheap source of labor. A competitor, partner, supplier and security risk.

headline: Trump Threatens Tariffs on Mexico. Have Any of His Immigration Measures Worked?
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Immigration Detention', 'Customs (Tariff)']
abstract: A look at President Trump’s efforts to halt the flow of Central American migrants on the southern border.
lead_paragraph: President Trump has called for imposing tariffs on Mexico, the administration’s latest attempt to slow the stream of migrant families who have been arriving at the southwest border by the thousands each day.

headline: The ‘Gravity Knife’ Led to Thousands of Questionable Arrests. Now It’s Legal.
abstract: Black and Latino men had often been charged under New York’s unusual ban on the knives, which are opened with a flick of the wrist.
lead_paragraph: Over the past 60 years, tens of thousands of black and Latino New Yorkers have been arrested for carrying so-called gravity knives — small, easy-to-access blades that are used by everyone from stagehands to steelworkers.

headline: When the Levees Break Again
abstract: New Orleans, its flood protections verging on obsolete, lives on the edge of disaster.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Saturday is the official start of hurricane season. And the Army Corps of Engineers recently predicted that our levee system may soon be obsolete.

headline: Memorial Tournament: Bud Cauley Makes a Stunning Comeback 1 Year After an Alarming Car Crash
abstract: Cauley, who has never won on the PGA Tour, is in contention at the Memorial a year after he was badly injured as a passenger in a single-car accident near the tournament site.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN, Ohio — Bud Cauley arrived in town Monday for the Memorial Tournament and was asleep in bed as the clock approached midnight. That’s where he wished he had been on the Friday of last year’s event, when he sustained serious injuries as a passenger in a late-night, single-car accident.

headline: Ocasio-Cortez Went Back to Bartending. Slogans Were Served.
keywords: ['Wages and Salaries', 'Minimum Wage', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Waiters and Waitresses', 'Bartenders']
abstract: The congresswoman, who has often cited her former restaurant job to emphasize her roots, mounted a classic political stunt to promote higher pay for tipped-wage workers.
lead_paragraph: Officially, Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez’s one-hour return to her bartending days was about a push to raise pay for tipped-wage workers.

headline: Frank Lucas Dies at 88; Drug Kingpin Depicted in ‘American Gangster’
abstract: His rise from poverty to riches through a drug-smuggling enterprise was a larger-than-life tale of ambition, organization and ruthless brutality.
lead_paragraph: As the Vietnam War raged in the late 1960s and early ′70s, a potent heroin called “Blue Magic” flooded into Harlem and Newark from a mysterious Southeast Asian connection. It destroyed lives, and it turned a black gangster named Frank Lucas into one of America’s most notorious drug kingpins.

headline: LaSalle Leffall Jr., 89, Dies; Cancer Society’s First Black Leader
abstract: A prominent surgeon and Howard University professor, he promoted awareness of the risks of cancer, particularly among African-Americans.
lead_paragraph: Dr. LaSalle D. Leffall Jr., a surgeon and educator who as the first black president of the American Cancer Society was a leader in promoting awareness of the risks of cancer, particularly among African-Americans, died on May 25 in Washington. He was 89.

headline: Yankees Keep Rolling, Right Over the Red Sox
abstract: Despite their many injuries, the Yankees have outpaced Boston and show no signs of slowing down with several stars on the road to return.
lead_paragraph: The fleeting moment has stuck with Aaron Boone. Last spring, in a spellbinding game at Yankee Stadium against the Boston Red Sox, third baseman Miguel Andujar turned to Boone, the Yankees’ manager, with the wonder of a rookie who had finally, truly made it.
